headline: My 2 cents being in NT
pros:
â€¢Decent WLB
â€¢Company provides amenities, Health insurance for self, spouse, parents, 2-way cabs throughout the city, food court and a break out area to cool down. 
â€¢ Management is very accessible and frequent skip level meetings to address concerns 
â€¢ Departmental activities and frequent interactions 
â€¢ cross process training and good learning of various process 
â€¢ Good place to start your career
cons:
â€¢WLB could be managed better 
â€¢CTC is very low, below industry standards but there is enough in hand to live comfortable Because of allowances. 
â€¢ work can be be monotonous with little scope for improvement in it 
â€¢internal politics due to a lot of process control being with one or two people having process knowledge and they opt to keep in that way to be indespensible ( impacting subordinates and management) 
â€¢ promotions in certain departments are very slow and hikes are usually ranging from 5% to 7%

headline: Competitive Salary, Collegial Environment
pros: The salary is enough to live in a great neighborhood in Chicago and enjoy a good lifestyle. You do not have to have an accounting degree for this position, although they do look for a couple of college accounting courses (my background was in finance). Everyone is very friendly and willing to help you acclimate and learn.
cons: This is an exempt position, so there is no overtime pay. During the busy season (1st quarter of the year), the job requires long hours and some weekends. The learning curve is also steep, but management realizes this and provide good training and mentorship and they acknowledge and expect it to be a learning process.

headline: Great company!
pros: Work life balance is great, opportunities for advance and trying new things
cons: Pay is not as competitive, slow to adopt new technologies

headline: Partner Focused
pros:
1. If you aim to develop your career, or yourself, NT has a lot to offer. They offer multiple Education Assistance Programs, they also have multiple trainings (Thousands) available for different job levels (individual contributors, managers, etc), the training offered are diverse in terms of coverage - whether it be technical skills, analytical, business acumen, self-development, presentation skills, etc. and they advocate that partners on their growth. They also have mentorship programs.

2. Multiple non-BAU engagements - scaling from your own team up to site level and global level
3. CSR is big thing!
4. Partners feedback are looked into
5. Multirater - partners (nominated by yourself) give formal feedbacks to you via a platform, and to their managers
6. Midyear and Annual performance discussion let's you in on your expected performance and how well you are doing - this are mandatory. The mid-year discussion, I would say is very important as this is your benchmark on what will be your estimated annual rating, and this gives you the opportunity to do better as well.
7. Pretty easy taking a leave, of course it depends on the peak cycle.
cons:
1. Not a lot of bonuses as compared to other companies that I know of. We only have the annual (performance bonus)
2. Conservative and risk-averse
3. Salary increase is not that high, very dependent on company profit and index benchmark. However, if you are an external hire, the salary offer is competitive.

headline: Best suited if you are a Politician
pros: Good for an Analyst but not higher up the ladder.
cons: Best place to work if you are good with politics and can grow by buttering the management. Worked for Securites Lending Department where management prefers hiring submissive people who can fulfil their wimps and fantasies, without questioning. Politics in my dept was the daily norm and the managers are strictly advised by top management not to get involved in the process and lack the basic product knowledge. If someone takes a stand and points out the injustices taking place, their names are tarnished and the employee is literally portrayed as the enemy of the state, including their ratings and hikes getting sabotaged. I arrived at a situation where the management made it impossible to work peacefully with their dirty politics.  Management are arrogant and make people slug at miserable salaries, overtime aren't paid and people are forced not to record overtime to avoid getting questioned. Pray you do not get into Northern and if you manage to get into, pray that you don't land up in Securities Lending.

headline: OTC Hedge Fund Services - Entry level at best
pros:
Exposure to high touch, big name clients 
Buy side/Sell side exposure 
Intro to middle office work
New office space in the loop
Should be viewed as entry level not career progression
cons:
Depending on the client, very high volume of breaks and operational tasks. Spend most of your day working with offshore teams and trying to fix breaks from the day before. 

There is no obvious difference between Analyst/Sr Analyst/Consultant/Sr Consultant. Everyone does the same thing. 

In three years I saw no one move internally in OTC. Just left for other roles at the bank or other companies. No real mobility in the OTC space. 

NT is not able or motivated to fill empty roles quickly. The work gets redistributed among the rest.

Many layers of management and red tape. Corporate as can be.

headline: Law of Diminishing Returns
pros:
A good place to start your career if you are right out of college.
Job Security
Plenty of leaves
cons:
Work life balance purely depends on which team you end up in. Stay away from the Data Management, Fund accounting & Pricing teams â€“ horrible managers, training is inadequate and the staff is most likely to be burned out with the huge volumes. 
Escalations and erratic decision making: Most of senior management donâ€™t understand the process they manage. The TLâ€™s rarely know what is happening within their own team and yet they enforce standard operation procedures which they donâ€™t fully understand. 
Lots of manual work. They implement controls and useless checks which only piles on the existing work pressure. 
Technology improvements are unprogressive. The applications used for business are outdated. Also, IT support is inadequate â€“ they really donâ€™t care about resolving IT issues are more concerned about cost cutting.
The pay is way below competitors. Hikes donâ€™t even match the inflation rate of the economy. Poor bonus figures. 
You only get recognized/ promoted if you grease your way up the ladder. Internal mobility is just for name-sake. IJP interviews are just a faÃ§ade for the managers who take the interview to show that they are open to diversity and change.
Utilize this platform to launch yourself to a better place - Donâ€™t get too comfortable as it will be difficult when you switch and go to new company.

headline: Stay Away!
pros: They still offer a pension. That is about it.
cons: Stay away from HFS. Very poorly managed. Focused on revenue growth and not on servicing the client. Poor investment in technology, falling behind to other competitors and are trying to play catch up. No respect for the work force. The culture is toxic, and lots of the seasoned people there are rude and have attitudes and are not willing to help. They just had a round of cuts, only to have management send out an email about their expensive workout equipment while people were left scrambling looking for another job. Completely tone def. All this was done to save costs not realizing the optics for the rest of the group which is already understaffed. Now they have tons of turnover and are posting all over linked in that they are hiringâ€¦with enthusiasm. Donâ€™t be fooled. This is a very toxic workplace. You have been warned. Expectations will be similar to hedge fund, pay will be far less. They brag about internal mobility, which is non existent. During one of my interviews over Zoom, the COO was on her phone texting. Completely unprofessional. They also brag about D&I yet, when I reached out to the D&I group with suggestions on how to help the community around the Chicago area, it fell on deaf ears. Look past the fake enthusiasm on LinkedIn. Itâ€™s all a front.

headline: Decent but lagging
pros:
* Stable, especially during COVID
* Remote WFH Worked
* Handful of Intelligent and Talented colleagues to network 
* Strong Brand recognition
* Learned plenty of industry and product knowledge to grow out of college
* Culture, Value Based and tries to demonstrate with community outreach
*Decent benefits, more vacation time once an Officer
cons:
* Low Pay compared to Market, barely keeps up with inflation 
* Poor Technology for internal and external users. Clients know and are sticking for now. Partners handle aging technology wasting time and unknown product roadmap. 
* High outsourcing to Tempe and India areas but noticeable turnovers which are worsening operational efficiency - layoffs or leaving of partners and dealing with poorly trained replacements.
* Competent workers are piled on work load
*Training is lacking. Mainly shadowing whoever is available. Growing beyond is a personal initiative. 
* Diversity is a work in progress and an initiative that is recognized.

headline: Good place to work
pros:
The organization is spending lot on building tech team. You will get ample opportunity to learn new things. Organization is reducing the outsourcing work and getting it done by Northern partner. If you have some great idea, rest assured you will get resource to get it implemented. Higher management is very much approachable.

Compensation benefits are good
- You will get meal card above your CTC
- Shift allowance but it's low as compared to it's rival. [1200/Month] for 12:30 PM to 9:30 PM 
- Both ways cab or 4500/Month above your CTC.
- Good Health Insurance and low premium. Please note 15% Copay in parents claim. Full coverage for employees and his immediate family.
- Broadband reimbursement for 1250/Month.
cons:
Many times you will be given a big ship and nobody will assist you in sailing.
Tech teams are new so you will see lot of process not documented properly.

headline: Horrible
pros: You are provided with a meal card and can facility
cons:
The company hires in bulk from many degree colleges. I too was picked up via campus.

1. You might get a full night (graveyard shift) or if you are lucky you will get a good day shift. If you get in graveyard shift forget work-life balance you ll end up being a nocturnal animal.

2. Managers do not care for anything. I worked like a dog and my manager was busy on his phone with no work, playing games, taking long breaks and logging off on time while we the analysts extend work for 3 more hours ending up working for almost 14 hours a day

3. Dirty politics is very much present here. The team dose'nt treat everyone equally they just pay respect to your looks rather than skills and help is offered to the ones whom the seniors prefer while others rot in hell.

4. HR policies of having office relationships are a joke. The team in which I worked had 2 couples who were in a relationship the senior offered help to his partner when we all had to be treated equally as freshers.

5. Even if you die finish your work and die. No proper dinner breaks. You will be loaded with work and seniors will dump on you and relax.

6. Improper trainers will spoil your stay at office the assigning of buddy system is useless as your buddy himself will be busy. You are left all alone with no help here and join this firm only if you know to impress with looks and attire.

headline: Avoid at all costs
pros: -You will get a paycheck
cons:
I cannot even recommend staying here for even a year to get experience and then bouncing, your overall mood will take a dive even within that year. Save yourself the time and effort and apply elsewhere. Especially if you are young and right out of college, this place will leave a sour taste in your mouth. There are significantly better companies in the Chicagoland area that are way better.


-The pay is one of the lowest in the sector.

-They started cutting costs of living wage increases.

-You will work extremely long hours. And on weekends. If you don't, well you'll just find more work on your desk to make up for the time that you could have been working during your off hours.

-You will in essence be punished for taking time off as everything that happened during your time off is waiting for you. There is no well oiled machine that continues to function while you are gone. Unfortunately, I found this true for the multiple teams I was on.

-Technology is absolutely horrible. Insanely horrible. And very little is being done about it. Processes continue to be bogged down by infrastructure that fails very often.

-IT will not be able to help you, so you better brush up on your technology skills.

-You are set up to fail, not to succeed. If you succeed, good for you, you can overcome it.

-You will be treated like cattle. Management doesn't care what you think or how you feel.

-Your voice will not be heard, no matter how important it may be.

-Way too much bureaucratic hurdles. I've seen issues take hours to find the right person or team that is responsible for resolving an issue only for it to be resolved within 3 minutes after finding that person.

-The burnout is horrible, they will work you to the bone, then add more work on top of it.

-Good work ethic and positive attitude are only met with more work with no recognition for accomplishments. If you do work here, honestly, it would be better to do average or bare minimum.

-Too many bad apples that get power trips over a small manager position. This goes up the totem poll as well. Too many people are abusive and HR just buries their head in the sand. It's an HR nightmare here. I'm amazed more people have come forward and brought up more lawsuits.

-Office politics get in the way of a lot. So many people talk behind each other's backs and becomes very cliquey very fast.

-Not much room for advancement unless you know certain people who will push it through.

-All work regarding updated systems or projects is outsourced or push to contractors so it is difficult to get funding for fixing issues or pushing ahead on new projects.

-Massive push on cost cutting so any nice things that were once had are being cut.

-In short, it feels like you are being exploited. It is very much a "Look out for yourself" culture. Trusting people here opens up vulnerabilities to make your life harder.

-Benefits are fine but lacking when you look at other companies in the area.

-Due to the place being horrible to work at, turnover is high so workload is always high.

-They labeled water fountains as an amenity...that is the kind of "amenities" to except from them.

headline: Bad outweighs the good

Lack of training and bad management are huge issues. Integrating new team members into the team is non-existent. New employees are left to their own means, which hinders growth within the role. Micromanaging is prevalent. The team is constantly dealing with high turnover and insufficient number of people.  Good managers are leaving because of the bad ones and no one is doing anything to address the issue. Due to this, moving jobs internally, as well as growth opportunities are hindered. headline: Do two years then leave
pros:
-Heart of downtown
-Job Security
-Easy banking hours
-There are some talented people you can connect with
- Brand recognition
-Great for someone fresh out of college.
-You cant realistically be fired
cons:
Kiss up Kickdown Culture
Growth Opportunities are virtually non existent
Pay is below industry average 
Top performers receive all of the work and none of the rewards
Bonuses are flat (I.E not tied to performance). Everyone gets roughly the same bonus target regardless of input.
Job growth is almost exclusively dictated by tenure. Older managers that have been grandfathered in may not actually have superb skills. (Example: a Senior Consultant once asked an analyst how to make a cell negative in excel.)
Conservative culture has draining office politics
All work is being moved to Tempe and India. There was more hiring and growth in India officially then in the U.S. for the past few years. 
This emphasis on cost cutting has made retaining decent talent impossible causing an attrition rate of roughly 33% yearly for the team. This has furthered a lack of social cohesion as most management doesn't even attempt to retain its workforce because they expect everyone to leave.

headline: DV is not for the faint of heart
pros:
- A paycheck
- Some professional experience
- Start with 3 weeks vacation but even that is limited to specific windows each month
- Job security. Even the worst analysts aren't fired despite showing negative job performance and growth over time
cons:
Most of this is specific to DV so I can't speak for other departments.

- The pay is abysmally low, far below market value

- Hours are always in flux and any overtime is frowned upon even if it's due to late prices or customer requirements.

- Technology is woefully outdated and cannot keep up with the always increasing client-specific reporting

- Poorly performing analysts are allowed to remain simply because there aren't enough people staying aboard the ship

- Office politics. Some people have a monopoly on certain vacation windows because tradition is more important than equity. Also, some high-performing analysts are passed over for promotion for reasons unknown.

- Administrators do not care about the capabilities of the department. They just give the clients whatever they want and expect DV to figure it out for them.

- There is minimal room for career growth and DV often leaves people pigeon-holed while also providing little in the way of transferable skills outside the company

headline: DO NOT WORK HERE ITS A WASTE OF YOUR TIME
author_position: Senior Consultant Middle Office Trade Processing
pros:
There are some pros to working at Northern. If you come in at a more senior level above vice president you're life is going to be fairly easy the organization is very top down so new initiatives end up on desk of entry level hires. While upper management is very removed from the process. 

Depending on which department you're in the hours can either be very reasonable or absolutely terrible.

You may qualify for a pension plan so if you end up in an easy role you can easily coast for a long time and you can retire with a nice pension.
cons:
YOU WILL NEVER RECEIVE YOUR FULL BONUS NO NO MATTER HOW HARD YOU WORK OR HOW WELL YOU PERFORM SO DO NOT WORK HERE

Rarely will you ever receive a raise outside of a cost of living adjustment, most of the time these cost of living adjustments don't keep pace with inflation

Benefits aren't great and are employee contributions are high.

little to no internal mobility

little to no career progression

high turnover

Most of the higher level people at northern trust are productivity predators. They know there is a constant cycle of new hires. They pawn off as much of their work on the new people who don't know yet that their hard work isn't rewarded, and they continue to coast. (See pro of coming into the company at a higher level above)

Jobs are very insulated rarely will you have contact outside of your team making internal mobility difficult.

People that work at northern are generally, lazy, unproductive, and unhelpful. There are a lot of people who have been working at NT for a long time and are just trying to ride it out until they can retire with their pension.

headline: Poor salary and work life balance
pros:
They will pay for some qualifications - but only if they're directly related to your role
Nice coworkers
Work from home flexibility
cons:
Poor organisation of business processes in general - focus on producing work and not improving efficiency of processes.

Long hours - team members are frequently online until 7 and after that

Large workload - work is piled onto junior team members, often to make up for the inefficiency of others. Outdated systems make it so that it will take days to complete certain tasks

Very training in general - people are thrown into work they have no prior experience with and expected to produce results immediately. Attitude towards training from some people is incredibly casual

Very outdated software. Constant IT problems meaning you can't complete the already unfair workload.

No overtime, you are forced to complete your work in the 9-5 window which is often not possible.

headline: Look Elsewhere
pros: Not much anymore really to say. Some nice coworkers.
cons: Been at the company for years and its only be declining. I do not know where are all of these 5 star reviews come from, but do not seem truthful to me. This company underpays, outsources like crazy nowadays, and even if you want to move up in the company, you really have to know someone. You may get interviews, but do not get your hopes up if you do not know the "right" person in the department. So, unless you are desperate, look elsewhere; working here is not worth the mental stress of the low salary along with the uncertain outlook here. I know many people here who simply "just get by" and get rewarded all the same for the people who put it in the work.

headline: Good company if you are in good team

Good HR policies
Good inclusion policies
Good values and ethics
Good work-life balance
Chilled environment
cons:
Management is very passive

Promotions are tenure based not performance based
In-house promoted managers have no idea how professional work culture should be, managers follow favoritism.
Also, they expect their Analyst to follow certain rules, but managers/ TLs do not follow it themselves
Management never leads from the front, but back-stabs you if they get chance
Managers, specially internally promoted Team Leaders are not familiar with concept of people management, they think only approving leaves and time sheet is their job.
Team Leaders make you cry for your own leave
** All I have mentioned is about team I was working in, NT is very big in itself, and if you fall under good manager, you will end-up learning a lot!

Learning for Freshers

headline: Great pay for entry level work
pros:
You start off with great pay for an entry-level position
Pension and 401K plan
Great insurance options
Can be work from home
cons:
Difficult to move up- you really really have to be top-notch
Your Increases/Bonuses are heavily dependent on the companies performance and it's possible that you could get no increase even if you moved up Title-wise if the company did not do so great that year. ( EX analyst to SR analyst.)
There are only specific times in the year where it's even possible to be promoted and the gaps between those timeframes are pretty long.

headline: Great place to work
pros:
-Start off with 4 weeks of vacation, 2 personal holidays, and almost every Federal holiday off.
-My team has had flexible working arrangements, even before COVID. We have the ability to work from home 4 days a week.
-The people at Northern are great! It's been great getting to work with people all over the globe.
cons:
-Pay is not the best. Northern Trust has been cutting expenses and bonuses over the past few years.
-There is not a lot of room for advancement. There is a saying you have to leave Northern to come back to Northern.
-There is not always a great work-life balance. Our team is very lean and I often find myself working more than 40 hours a week for below-market pay.

headline: Worst years of my life
pros: In hindsight, I can't think of any pros of working at Northern Trust. It's very much a top-down organization run by middle-aged white men, and those who want to be middle-aged white men. While they brag about their diversity, they always trot out the same 2 or three senior employees from under-represented populations and say, "See? We're diverse!" But if you don't think and act and speak like a middle-aged white man, you'll never be on the inside. And these same white men don't like anyone over the age of 50, either. Unless it's another white male.
cons: At Northern Trust, everyone is out for whatever they can get. They'll malign you behind your back. They'll lie to you, undermine your efforts, and make sure every day to torture you. Unless you're 30, pretty, and wealthy. Or a legacy. Or are in a position of power. But even those persons are at risk. Since "culture," whatever that is, trickles downhill, that could be the reason why everyone in wealth management is treated so poorly. What you have left are a bunch of angry, no talent defensive slackers who are hanging on until retirement.

headline: If youâ€™re eager to learn and want to advance your career, skip this company
pros: Benefits, vacation, hard to think of anything else
cons: If you are looking to work in the Tempe office and are hoping for career advancement, challenging opportunities, learning new skills, and a hard work pays off attitude then hard stop here....run! You will be better off at almost any other company on earth than this one.  Asset Management plays favorites if you arenâ€™t from the Chicago office or â€œone of the original employeesâ€ then you could create a way for the company to save millions and still never be looked at as intelligent.  Most employees that have been in this organization for years are at best seat warmers.  They do nothing but arenâ€™t afraid to intimidate everyone to keep their perceived idea of power.  Turnover with brilliant new talent is the norm, no one smart enough to have another job stays longer than a couple of years.  The only skill you will learn here is that of 5th grade talent cutting and pasting and manually fixing bad numbers that the computer systems canâ€™t seem to calculate correctly and if you miss a few bad numbers no big deal it goes to clients and no one cares.  Save yourself time and search elsewhere.

headline: Avoid
pros:
Health insurance
The location
WFH possibilities
Gym when not in pandemic
cons:
In house systems constantly crash
I needed health insurance just to get by in this job.
Pay is low and overtime is heavily discouraged... (work must be completed)
Training was good from some trainers and incredibly flippant from others.
Felt poorly treated daily.
Politics amongst management is the game.
Most of the team are often still working at 7pm regularly and later sometimes. 
Management heads home before COB even at months-end leaving all the work and ad-hoc issues to analysts.
Forward on from October 2019 to 9 months later, 80% of analysts on my team had departed, at least one with no alternative job to go to.
Need to be a self starter as there is a high chance you won't be trained fairly. If self-starter, go to big four for an accounting/graduate role and look at finance later in your career. 
No team building. No good mornings, no positive feedback, nothing like this existed on my team. No positivity period, from local management. It's not enough that the only positive words you will ever hear are coming from Dublin management. It doesn't make up for the approach i experienced in Limerick.

headline: Great place if youâ€™re a heteronormative, entitled, white male; not so great otherwise.
pros:
-	You will *not* work yourself to death there. In fact, you will most likely do rather little.
-	The moneyâ€™s alright, particularly in light of the fact that you will not be doing very much.
-	Itâ€™s a great place if youâ€™re a 35+ white male and you donâ€™t have any particular ambitions â€“ you just want a place to last at until retirement.
-	It may be dysfunctional and unpleasant, but itâ€™s not an evil environment per se; not many psychopaths.
cons:
Northern Trust in 2020â€™s is what banks and asset managers must have been in the 1980â€™s / 1990â€™s. It is so culturally backwards itâ€™s quite phenomenal. Progression is blocked for anyone who is not a white, heteronormative male (ideally with some old money lineage). It is not explicit discrimination of course, itâ€™s just the long-established culture. Basically mediocre white guys with degrees in feeling good about themselves promoting others just like them. The levels of homophobia are well above average, though most of it is implicit. Many LGBT+ employees keep their orientation private in fear of their careers. That fear is well justified â€“ any â€œotherâ€ has little future at NT: female, Asian, brown, olive, gay, trans, immigrant â€“ they can all just forget it. The company is trying to project this image of â€œdiversity by acquisitionâ€ through its non-executive directors. This is cynical and no one inside the company is buying it: non-execs can be minorities or female, but they have little to say in how the company is being run.

It is particularly unfortunate to see how NT works for women. Women have only got 2 choices at NT:
-	either to dumb themselves down, pretend to be warm, fuzzy, fluffy, and really stupid so as not to make the men feel threatened;
-	or to become absolute psycho-monsters, Glenn Close- / Rebecca DeMornay-type bunny boilers who out-evil the men at their own game.
I saw both in spades, and found it cringe-worthy. NT is no place for women â€“ especially women of colour. They can forget about *any* development or career at NT. Sadly, this also applies to the Indian offices, where NT has some 3,000 back-office employees. Vast majority of management are male, and some of them are just *awful*. The kind of things they are allowed to get away with just because they are cheaper than their European counterparts is upsetting.

Managers routinely take all credit for their teamâ€™s work. At times it can be quite comical â€“ they will take the report printout from their team and present it as their sole, own work in front of that very team. More often than not they will have never read that actual report â€“ theyâ€™d scan it in a meeting for 3 minutes and base their teamsâ€™ annual reviews on it.
NT will also actively *discourage* professional growth and development. This will manifest itself not only through refusal of any monetary support or extra time off. Whenever possible, they will go an extra mile to derail it. NT is not a place where smarts count for very much.

Any thought leadership? Forget about it; NT is all about its 130+ yearsâ€™ of heritage. There is *no* thought leadership at NT.
Technologically itâ€™s the most backwards firm Iâ€™ve ever seen â€“ itâ€™s quite phenomenal it holds together (I doubt it will for very much longer). Itâ€™s a complete hodgepodge of jumbled systems and mainframes (sic!); hardly anyone knows how they run. Around 2010 the company spent close to USD 500mln on technological transformation â€“ it ended up with hundreds of people hired to do no-one-knows-what, no actual deliverables, and a handful of sacked executives. That is very symptomatic of NT.

headline: Worst Company with Worst Management
pros: Short commute, able to work from home
cons:
Northern Trust is where careers go to die. If you care about your career, please don't come here. The managers here are totally incompetent. I have never seen such a terrible workplace. The worst dept is Corporate Actions. Everyone I speak with is looking to quit. Bonuses and raises are way below average (and less than what they tell you in interviews) - this is why they pay bonuses in April - this way they force people to stay longer than they really wanted to. Outdated computer systems that always crash. No one is ever promoted. All managers come from outside - unless you've been with the company when they merged with a division from Citadel many years ago. 

Management is completely clueless as to the work. No idea how to lead a team. Revolving door of employees. Everyone is looking to quit.

Also, the managers lie about everything just for CYA purposes. The technology is the worst in the industry - old and in the 3+ years, I've been here, it has never been updated. Management doesn't do anything; however, if you make a mistake, this is an opportunity for them to actually do some work - which is to attack you. Prepare yourself for 200+ emails every single day - not a joke.

You don't have to believe me. Join the company and you will see for yourself. There are people who quit NT without a job because they are that miserable - I'm at that point now.

headline: Great company, but slow career progress and ruined by some bad managers
pros:
-A very successful global company offering great services
-Nice office location
-Low staff turnover â€œa job for lifeâ€
-Good salary on joining
cons:
-A great D&I agenda for a great company that sadly today still has glass ceilings for women and people of colour. 
-In certain departments, clubs of â€œprivileged white malesâ€ existed in senior management, promoting/ rewarding their friends with seemingly no oversight/ accountability. 
-Long hours needed to do your job properly, although this has improved.
-Salary increases and bonuses left me 20% below market rate after 5 years.
-Lots of layers of hierarchy for people sitting at the same bank of desks doing the same job!
-Huge risk of just â€œgetting stuckâ€ in your career. Lots of people in the exact-same jobs for 20+ years. This created a body of people with limited skillsets who were resistant to change or to moving towards more efficient ways of working.

headline: Not a good long term place for millennials and college grads.
pros: Steady paycheck, some managers are great people
cons:
1. Pay is based on tenure, not results. Your salary will be much lower than your peers, even if you outperform them.

2. Your work ethic and energy will be exploited and senior management will take credit for how good the firm's margins are.

3. Lack of age/gender diversity in management.

4. A fixed pension that becomes vested after 5 years is not a good benefit for a young employee who has decades of market appreciation ahead of them. 

5.. Work from home limited in certain roles.

headline: The worst company to work with
pros: 5 days work, free transport, team outings, yearly bonus
cons:
This review can save your Career I made a big
mistake by joining this company. Since then I'm
leading a miserable life. There is no work-life
balance here. You have to work each and
everyday for 10 to 12hrs like a donkey with all
that stress and hectic load. No time for your
family. Management is dead. they don't
understand the problem of employees. They
want to run the operations with minimum
resources. I literally work like a slave here.
Managers are like puppets and just behind the
targets. I don't get time to go for breakfast
lunch or dinner, most of the times I don't get up
to go for nature calls also. Just imagine the
level of stress imposed and working extra
houra everyday. Please join this company if you
want to go not reachable to your family, make
your life hell, put your career at risk because
once you join here, then there is no way you can
get out. 9hrs job is a big myth here. I'm now
thinking of resigning this company after 3 yrs
of my service. I don't have any offers currently,
but that's better than dying here. My body has
finally stopped supporting the stress level I was
taking here.

headline: Stay of out IT here if you want to keep your sanity
pros: I honestly cannot think of any beyond gainful employment.
cons:
Cost seems to be the only factor in most upper management decisions. 

There is a push to move as many positions as posible to India. The majority of people in IT do not understand English very well, which makes it incredibly difficult to do complex, intricate IT work.

The  company is run very similarly to a kindergarten or preschool in regards to its training courses and messaging to employees, who are grown adults.

The company does not pay high enough salaries to attract or retain quality employees. 

In IT 70% of the staff is contractors. Most contractors are not based in the US and are new to the company. It typically takes 3 - 5 calls to the Help Desk to resolve any kind of technical issue. The bank outsources a lot. The companies that the bank outsources to do not have the capabilities to meet the bank's needs. 

The bank likes to implement as much burdensome process as possible vs. simplifying and removing administrative overhead. The amount of time I spend doing real, value-add work during any given day is probably under 30%.

headline: Bureaucratic, political & non-meritocratic
pros:
- There are diamonds (honest, hardworking people) in the rough, and they tend to pull entire teams (good old 80/20 rule)

- Benefits are fair (cheap medical & dental, decent retirement matching)
cons:
- Compensation 10-20% below competitors; bonus structure does not reward hard work (0.5% in some cases)

- Exceedingly political work environment -- Poor performers are promoted for sticking around for a long time, dumping work on others, or playing the system/befriending the right people (relatedly, gossip is rampant, since many are well aware of these facts, and need an outlet for the dissonance they feel)

- I witnessed 4 very good employees leave or quit during my tenure (even without another job lined up), due to frustration with management & political game playing

headline: A great company, a terrible institutional product management team.

Not just diversity from a protected category perspective but also diversity of ideas and thoughts.  The worse institutional product group. A senior manager of product team, in London, has no experience in product, completely lacks diversity and her boss has inappropriate relations with some of his directs.  Then there are other managers who have no clue about product management but are given responsibility to lead professional product manager so you can imagine terrible results and outcomes.

headline: Just wasn't for me, but still proceed with caution.
pros: Great hours, start early so we can leave early in the Tempe location, lines up with standard Chicago business hours (central time).
cons: Admittedly, I didn't really fit into the team culture very much, which is a first in any role I ever had and had a difficult time understanding it, so most of it is on me. Training for the role wasn't great and felt overwhelmed most of the time. It feels very clique-ish and you can tell right away who is tight with management and who isn't (me). Felt kind of like an outsider the majority of the time and the environment is very intimidating and borderline toxic if they view you unfit right away. In one year witnessed three people get fired, all individuals who were working there a year or less. They say they are patient with those learning the role and learning at a different pace than others, but didn't feel this was the case for me.

headline: Good Bank, Great culture and then comes the spineless Indian Management
pros: Great Culture, good bank to start career, Chicago Management were proactive, good Leadership. Very stable.
cons:
Salaries as years go by gets stagnated. Unless you try and move departments internally you get stuck with monotonous work. Indian management hit or miss. A lot of time is spent by managers impressing higher management and being a yes man or pulling other people down. Managers lack skills overall in being a mentor and come through the rank internally and have a set mindset and don't want to change.

Work life balance doesn't exist and it's a bad trend people follow looking at their managers who spend 13-14 hrs a day and also being in the night shift. In the long run affects the health.

Trainings are not effective to build skills. If you have more aspirations then you are better off using this as a start. Nothing against the company just the Indian management fails to ignite creativity and really stomp authority nipping all the creative people in the bud.

cons: Office morale is always at some sort of low. Very political environment and itâ€™s all about whoâ€™s in charge and if youâ€™re a favorite or not. Some partners work very hard and get paid well below what the standard set forth by the company or even below basic cost of living for the particular role and location.  Technology, although on the rise, is lacking and some days you spend most of your time just trying to get your computer to go online. Poorly trained middle and senior managers have NO idea how to handle direct reports. Pay is below industry standard. Technology on client-facing end is woefully lacking and embarrassingly substandard. Products are too often behind the times and/or poorly conceived.  They try to implement diversity programs but often fail at being as inclusive as they pretend they are. It's still an old white guy's bank!

headline: Had an awesome experience working at NT
pros: Good benefits, perks, salary, good growth, team outings
cons: Long working hours, tight deadline

headline: Rewarding Place to Start a Career in Finance
pros:
1) Opportunity  for Learning and Growth

Working on the client audit team provides tremendous experience for someone early in their career. Client Audit sits at the end of the custody reporting process within Alternatives at Northern Trust. The team is responsible for gathering and auditing the work of several other teams within the department before signing off on monthly reporting. This gives client audit exposure into what the other teams do and what the clients are looking for from a custodian. There is great opportunity for someone who is willing to work hard and learn the process. It also provides insight into an asset class that is becoming more and more popular with investors.

2) Supportive Management and Team Culture

I had a very good manager during my time with the Client Audit Team. I felt that she was always trying to help me advance my career and grow as an employee. I was able to learn a lot about banking operations and people management in my time with the team.  Overall, I think the leadership group does a great job with the team.

The culture of Client Audit is also very strong.  The team is big (20+ total) but very supportive to new employees. Team members are always willing to help when one person may be struggling. It's a great group of people to work with every day.

3) Solid, Respected Company

Northern Trust is a good company to work for. The culture is extremely friendly and supportive. There is tremendous opportunity to grow within your own department or with other groups. Senior management is very accessible. I think this is why you see so many people staying with NT for such a long time.
cons:
The main downside of working on the Alts Client Audit Team is the overtime required during the first 2 weeks of each month. 

Client Audit's main responsibility is to collect information from investment managers and signoff on monthly custody reporting.  The issue is that all of the information is made available at the same time, and all clients seem to want reporting on the same day each month. This leads to Client Audit working a significant amount of overtime early in the month. This is paid overtime, but the days can be long, particularly when the same cycle happens every 4 weeks.

headline: Rotational Development Program (Technology)
pros:
* Very light work hours (never expected to go over 40 hours) and the environment is low stress

* Starting salary was solid (80k) for the Chicago market, especially given the low number of hours expected.
cons:
* Engineering talent is non-existent. Mostly consists of people with archaic skills that have been at the company forever and contractors from Infosys, Contractors, etc.

* Better off jumping ship after a year to significantly increase salary since raise and bonus were very weak, especially given how hot the tech market has been.

* If you do the RDP Program, high probability that you will be placed in at least one undesirable rotation either working on legacy systems or doing work that doesn't even involve programming.

* Even if you get a rotation that involves significant programming, very few difficult/interesting engineering problems. Best you can really hope for is doing fairly modern front-end development.

Great offices..again if you're downtown. 
Overall working at Northern is what you make of it. If you are in the Asset Management or Wealth Management side of the bank you will have a great job, decent pay, and good work-life balance.  Operations side is a different story, but that's the case industry wide. As a company, particularly as a bank, Northern has to keep their operating costs low and unfortunately the roles in operations are the biggest money draining roles in the company. The good part is that Northern promotes from within, and if you have the drive and work ethic you can manage to shift to a WM or AM role.
cons: Relatively low pay.  Some departments are truly soul sucking.

headline: Marketing Professional
pros:
There are a lot of very nice people working here. Thought leaders are extremely knowledgeable and there is a deep bench of talent with specialized expertise. 

The company has a great reputation and a unique client base. They have wonderful (and generous) programs in place for the communities where the NT offices are located.

Seem to be hiring a lot of Millennials.
cons:
Although some areas of NT are more innovative in their thinking (50 South Capital, CX Lab, FlexShares, etc.), I found my experience to differ.  Wealth Management moves very slowly and quite frugal when it comes to resources for "high value" employees (software applications , training & leadership, cross channel relationship building, networking events, advancing career paths, etc.).  

It can take up to a year to complete a 10 page sales presentation because there is not a clear owner (and the stakeholders can't come to an agreement on the content or look and feel).

The culture takes a bit of getting used to. From my POV, I could see a defined hierarchy and a true chain of command in place throughout the organization. For example, I once had a manager try to deter me from introducing myself to a presenter after an internal 'town hall'  meeting. I'm a polished professional and just wanted to tell them "thank you" for covering the topic and to volunteer my time outside of my role to assist with the initiative.  Also, it was frowned upon to directly send an email to a senior partner or executive without getting buy in or permission from your manager. Weird.

Our team was consistently being pulled aside to address "emergency" situations which would lead to other priority projects being late (change in leadership, regulatory situations, economic disruption, a SME needed a paper produced in three days, etc.). 

They seem to be hiring a lot of Millennials.  It's obvious that partners who have had family members work here (during or prior to joining), are exposed to more career opportunities or coddled a bit more.

headline: Hedge Fund Services - Get out after two years
pros:
Good job out of college if you have no better options, or hate your current job.
You make an immediate impact which affects clients, projects, or other teams. Exposure to this is beneficial to your early career.
Top top HFS management know what they are doing. This helps drive future business.
Good work/life balance. You should be able to get away with working 8 hours a day.
Ability to work from home, especially if you have kids.
Good amount of vacation days, typical medical/dental/vision benefits.
You won't get fired. Unless you're extremely bad at your job.
cons:
Training was abysmal. I left after a few years and it never got better. Nothing is centralized and knowledge is lost when people leave. You will learn by sitting at someone's desk and jotting notes on paper. Complete joke.
Technology is sourced from Citadel. When you leave HFS, all that knowledge disappears and cannot be carried to other companies.
A lot of management and senior management is ex-Citadel. Impossible to move up. Certainly a lot of these people are 'lifers'. During my time, I don't believe I saw anyone replace their manager. Only way is to transition to another team (don't do this, you will make more $ by leaving)
A lot of incompetent managers/older employees with no technology/Excel skills. They will find young talent and pawn off majority of the work on them. My experience was I had no choice and had to complete the work under constant monitoring. Google 'fear-based leader'.
They've opened up a Tempe, AZ office which will definitely be replacing new jobs located in Chicago. May affect raises, offers, bonus, etc....
Pay increases were a complete joke. You have to fight for it, be super aggressive, and threaten to get big bumps. They will never hand out big pay increases based on your actual value.
I never got my total bonus target. You will likely receive 66% of the 'target %'.
Northern Trust is a custody bank. They can have an amazing year and employees will see an extra 1-2% bonus. Rest goes to shareholders.
Happy hours/group outings paid by NT disappeared. Again, NT is super cheap. Very difficult to get to know your employees/new employees.

headline: Alts Analyst
pros: Benefits aren't the worst- not great medical, but not terrible. OK 401k. A lot of people stick around for the pension which you are eligible for after 3 years.
cons:
I made this review because I noticed a lot of highly positive reviews as of late- this is because management of many of the teams held meetings and asked employees to leave positive reviews due to the negative reviews posted at the time, but I don't feel these accurately represent working at Northern Trust.
*HIGHLIGHTS: Poor salary, culture clash, no advancement, poor management*
So where to start...firstly, salary. Salary is low for the industry average, but pretty on par for the local area. Companies know they have a pipeline of new talent from ASU grads, and a lot of finance firms have operations offices in the Phoenix area, so while you won't get paid much, you won't get much higher unless you work in actual finance. The bonuses are SMALL. Even for employees rated as high performers, who only receive a fraction of a percentage higher than those who aren't.
Which brings me to the second area of discussion- the work itself. Don't be fooled by the recruiters or interviewers- all jobs in the Tempe office are Operations. During my time, I've seen a lot of people join the team (myself included) with the understanding that the job was completely different than what it was due to the interview tactics. Some people were straight up lied to about the job. They'll say anything to get you in the door. Why? The training is minimal. They don't have formal trainers, and most teams don't have formal training plans. It's a game of 'who has time to sit with the noob(s).' Because they don't invest in the training of their employees, they don't invest in retaining their employees because there is little value there. In periods of high turnover on the team, they simply put the extra work on other employees. And when employees take on more work, many teams decide to cap overtime hours in a comical lapse in judgement.
It's choices like these that reflect the management at Northern Trust. In alts, and in every department I have encountered. Management itself sees a high rate of turnover, but the constant seems to be managers that are controlling, ill-trained, and don't value employees (exceptions to this are rare). Any pitch of 'work/life balance' is because they don't want to pay you overtime. In reality, work life balance is hard to attain because getting time off can be difficult. Only a certain amount of people can be out on a team on any given day, and you're only expected to take time off when you have down time or no deadlines. 
Thirdly- the culture. I mentioned the pension in the Pros section. This is a great aspect of the company until it isn't. This means a lot of people are there to coast for as long as they can to get their pension. It makes it harder for people who want to actually come in and do good work to work with other teams and people. An older Glassdoor review said NT cuture is "Be seen and not heard." I think this is the most accurate thing I've read on here. Managers encourage innovation but don't want actual change, and see suggestions as complaints. There is also a HUGE culture clash with the Arizona natives vs. Chicago transplants. Chicago people are often viewed as 'elite' even though these will almost without fail be 1) the same people whos teams were moved to AZ because of poor performance and 2) are there to coast for their pension. Another fun twist to the culture is the fact that managers are brought in from India, and no matter what team you're on, somewhere down the line the Bangalore or other non-US team is handling your assets/accounts/clients/etc. This creates a huge opportunity for clashes in communication, culture, sense of urgency, etc.
In terms of career growth, this really varies by team. If you're on a team with a high rate of turnover and constant vacancies, chances are you'll be made senior after your first year but then stagnate in your career. Other than this, there may be some lateral growth but nothing outstanding.

headline: Transfer Agency Analyst
pros:
-Northern is a place where you can gain experience in the financial industry
-Front office roles in banking and investment management at Northern Trust can stack up with most other banks
-The company has a distinguished history and is respected in the industry
-You could potentially work abroad
-Good Chicago loop location
-Investment operations work can lead to an external investment consulting analyst or wealth management job after a couple of years, if you keep learn about markets and investing while at Northern and present your experience the right way
cons:
-Low pay, raises of 1% or less for everyone I worked with regardless of performance 
-Low morale, jaded employees are the norm 
-Lack of professional middle managers, my manager and assistant manager were demeaning bullies who did little work and managed with passive-aggressive emails
-Most managers in my department had open cases filed against them with HR for harassment but with no action taken
-High turnover
-Scant, informal training for many employees
-Little career direction or support
-Investment operations (which is most of the organization) work is dry at best
-Sausage factory: severe, assembly line environment

headline: Not what it used to be
pros: Work life balance, great reputation
cons: Northern Trust's once stalwart culture is going badly downhill. In wealth management, comp has gone to a black box discretionary model which rarely compensates employees for work put in or business won for the company. Managing directors vary greatly in talent and some appear to have been just promoted because of a clubby, old boys culture. Do not work here as a woman if you expect to advance or be treated fairly. Business goes to the favorites who are usually men.  Check out the C-Suite.  Conflict between wealth management brackets has increased greatly, creating a lot of territorialism and bad behavior much more reminiscent of Goldman Sachs than of "warm, cozy" Northern. Talent varies greatly across the organization. Comp far below market. Company moving toward a layoff culture.

headline: Two Years of Disappointment
pros: Northern Trust is extremely open to people moving positions after one year in their role.
cons:
* Most areas of NT have extremely high turnover (in particular, IOO and HFS have about a 33% turnover per year).  This creates debilitating issues in regards to morale and training.  Most critically, for example, the team I started on had five managers quit in 1.5 years.
* They never meet their bonus targets (e.g., up to 5% for Senior Analyst or up to 7% for Consultant).  My first year at NT, they informed us that salary increases were on hold indefinitely and hiring was frozen indefinitely (even as people were leaving voluntarily, their roles were not filled).  For bonuses, despite having an above-average review, I got a 1% bonus (I was eligible up to 5%); my second year, despite a promotion in title, I got a 1.8% bonus (I was eligible up to 7%).
* If you have an issue with a manager, HR is NOT on your side.  I filed a hostile work environment complaint against my direct manager, HR told my manager that I complained about him, and then I experienced extreme retaliation.  My manager denied any wrongdoing and I was verbatim told that they were taking his word as truth over mine because he is a manager.  (Note: this person has extreme turnover only with female staff and multiple women have complained to HR about him.)

headline: Analyst, Hedge Fund Services
pros:

-Everyone is considered a "partner" instead of an employee.

-Modern workplace with an emphasis on testing new technology. 
-Management is clear on communicating your career path progression. 
-Rewards are handed out to partners who perform well. 
-HFS is a smaller department within NT. Therefore, promotions can be fast tracked due to our growing nature.
cons:
-Each manager had their own take on HFS values. Some are good, some are bad. 
-HFS does not always follow the initiatives that NT as a whole pushes. For example, HFS frowns upon working from home unless absolutely necessary. 
-Some managers will play favorites. Resulting in certain partners getting the benefit of the doubt and others do not.

headline: Strong, balanced, dependable company
pros: The culture is strong and welcoming. It is not an aggressive or competitive place to work. The resources for employees and professions are wide-ranging, with plenty of opportunity to explore different types of work. The company performs strongly and is led by a strong, trusted and impressive management group. A fantastic place to grow and learn.
cons: The technology tools are sometimes too complicated or antiquated, which can get annoying. It doesn't prevent people from doing their jobs, but it does slow things down. The company has a lot of silos as well; there's been a lot of work to break down the silos across the different businesses but change is hard. Lastly, there are a lot of retirement age (or close to it) employees, which leaves tons of opportunity for career progression but the mindset among many of these employees makes it difficult to try new things or branch out.

At the executive levels, some are strong leaders and others are very poor leaders who cause unnecessary drama which results in low employee morale. Step up and lead by example. Would not recommend working here.

headline: Fund Reporting Department
pros: The pro of working at NT (as a whole) is their prestige, and their overall employee benefits including the employee discounts to museums. Also, NT has invested in their Tech infrastructure, and most functions are automated, so your main responsibility will be data validation/analysis. At, a department level, the only pro is  working shoulder to shoulder with the other accountants is really what make this job and department tolerable.
cons:
The only cons  at a company level, that I experienced, was dealing with HR.  They may be great at recruiting (although the pay is below market), but their ability to handle complaints is virtually non existent.  
At the department level, there were many factors that made the job intolerable, such as poor leadership with the section managers, the mandatory overtime, lack of account ownership/accountability within the department, communication between teams (grouped by section managers), lack of universal training.  Also, lack of advancement within the department was a major con.  
If you are young, I would highly recommend you not interview/accept the offer, because you will stunt your professional growth, as the process is so automated, you will not learn technical/profession skills.  This is also a large company, therefore you will often time be ignored/invisible to upper management.  The base pay is not competitive, and not an ideal scenario when you are trying to get established. This company/department would be an ideal workplace if you are close to retirement and want to enjoy the benefits (retirement, pension, flexible work hours etc). Also a good option, if you choose to be a "lifer" at a younger  age.  

For the record, I am basing the above on my experience at Northern Trust, and how I rate them relative to other companies that I have worked. I was content while working at NT, and stayed with the department for 4-7 years.  During that time, we had high turnover in staff and management, and overall restructuring of the client servicing department that was newly forming.   It has been awhile since I last worked there, but I keep in touch with several of the current accountants, and it doesn't seem like the root problem with the department has been addressed/solved.   They are still dealing with high turnover.   
 In conclusion,  I would recommend the company to a friend, but not the Fund Reporting Department. Job satisfaction really depends on what department you are placed, and not uniform across offices.

headline: Solid, smart, ethical people do well here
pros:
Northern Trust hires good people - the work environment is welcoming to all and teamwork and collaboration are emphasized.  Shady dealings and gray ethics are not tolerated which is refreshing.  Each person I have met over the past 10 years at this company really tries in their role.  There is a culture of doing your best and putting the clients first - this comes from the top down.  There are several reward programs in place to recognize efforts that parallel the core values of the Company.
Once you are a trusted partner and have earned your respect, it is relatively easy to transfer offices within the Company if you want or need to.
cons: I am not sure this is a "downside" but it is to some - this is a long term commitment.  If you want to come in as a stepping stone and leave, it isn't the place for you.  It is a family atmosphere where people care about each other.  People who are looking for a quick way to make a dollar should go elsewhere.  It is a career and you have to earn your respect and will get your rewards based on academic credentials, skills, professionalism and performance.

headline: Team Leader
pros: They offer tuition reimbursement after 6 months; Green Belt Six Sigma ; variety of organzations/ business resource groups to join for networking.
cons:
They have coined the phrase "Northern Culture" which is really just "be seen and not heard". They encourage employees to speak up and be courageous but they are black balled for doing it.  The opportunities for growth are limited and given to who upper managers deem as "ready" and weigh heavy on if you are "in" with the Directors.  If you didn't migrate down from Chicago you are pretty much out.

The salarys are way below market for the caliber of work they are expecting. They have high turn over for many reasons but being competitive is one for sure. 

The behavior allowed by emoloyees is repulsive. There are no guidelines on repercussions, so everything is left to management's discretion, hopefully they are not having a bad day. Too many gray areas for favouritism. Which I saw first hand.

headline: 2nd Vice President
pros: The benefits package and pension is very good
cons: The company structure and lack of any support, the management is based on micro management but also any lack of management support when it's needed. The whole structure is based on blame and who can take the fall. No ownership is ever taken and if it does it's very much swept under the carpet. There is an uncomfortable atmosphere and there are a lot of old pockets of staff that have been in the same roles for many years and lack any responsiveness to admitting errors, providing support or even open to change. The firm is built on its customer excellence however this is clearly lacking operationally internally. Unfortunately a very very toxic environment. Almost felt like working with a pack of fighting dogs.

headline: The Northern Trust way is old and tired
pros: Competitive benefits and decent wages.
cons: Ever since going public, the bottom line is to impress investors.  It's an old crony, good ol' boys select group of male leaders in key positions with very few female top executives. This company is all about doing more with less - less people, less resources, less  work/personal life balance.  They cram employees into small cubicles with the exception of those holding upper management positions. Even the department managers, in many departments, work in cubicles.  This makes it difficult to have meaningful conversation without disrupting other workers.

headline: Great benefits...that is all
pros: Great benefits package.  Received decent amount of vacation, sick, and "emergency days", as well as 401K and pension (who still does that?).  But that is all.
cons: I came in from the outside working over 25 years in the financial industry working for midsize to extremely large institutions.  It is true that there is rampant nepotism and incompetent management.  I have managed very large teams before and I could of ran circles around the person they assigned to manage the group.  The company as a whole is adverse to change.  High turn over of good people leaving the lazy lifers working for their pension.  I actually had a potential employer tell me he would not hiring anyone with Northern Trust on their resume.

headline: Hedge Fund Services - Production Services Team Lead
pros: Plenty of opportunities to learn and improve the organization. Many processes have not been changed since the firm was still Omnium and had ~20 clients. Management is somewhat malleable.
cons: While management is somewhat malleable they will not provide sufficient support to successfully implement change. You can work yourself virtually to the bone and seemingly get nowhere because there are so many changes that need to be made to scale the company and management does next to nothing to support the middle management down. Further, if you do work hard to push positive change you will become a scape goat within the organization. My team grew by nearly 500% in headcount and added several functional areas of responsibility over nearly four years. We developed automated solutions to real business problems with no technical support or proper tooling. We worked to mitigate risks associated with poor business practices in Quality Control specifically although we were constantly overruled by business units to their own detriment and subsequently bailed them out assisting in emergency break fix efforts. Yet through all the time, effort, and added stress I consistently barely beat inflation with my salary increases, my bonuses never met the advertised 15 percent, and I never received a title promotion. I`

Open ended shifts weekly, you have no idea when you will be leaving due to too many factors out of your control with pricing departments, derivative rates, etc.

headline: Northern Trust Institutional Fund Accounting
pros: Basically none.  I will say that on an analyst level, many coworkers are friendly, nice people.  The team that manages the dow account actually is made up of some smart, good guys.
cons: This review is specific to the institutional fund accounting team, I can't speak for the rest of Northern.  There is absolutely no reason to accept a role with that team. Management is a Dilbert level of incompetent, the office actually functions better when they are not there.  There is no room for career advancement.  Pay is bad compared to the industry.  The hours are terrible, it's not unusual for all the analysts to still be in the office past 9 PM.   The job teaches no transferable skills.  Everyone is trying to leave.  Turnover in six months was above 50%.  Upper level management is working on automating most of the department.  Management does a terrible job communicating, I remember a coworker who had been there almost two years getting yelled at for approaching the bosses cubicle without sending an instant message first, and that's just the tip of the iceberg.  Things just get worse.

From the CEO to the most of the business unit heads, they are self absorbed and completely out of touch with what is happening.  Unfortunately, this group has been stagnant for too long -- now is focused on "getting the stock price up" -- so that they can even further cash in before they retire.  In the meantime, they huddle on the third floor and try to figure out whom to blame for not meeting sales projections or stupid emails praising their own thoughts.  ('a approach, or 'my ideas on excellence").

headline: Alternative Assets Analyst

Once there are any issues, management does not hesitate to point fingers at lower level employees and include all issues in your reviews. This makes it impossible for anyone to advance to higher levels or even change departments within the bank. The treatment from managers in this areas has created lots of turnover and employees have taken massive pay cuts to leave this department. Northern Trust is a great company overall, but the alternative assets department has some very serious issues with their culture and processes.

headline: Internship Program
pros: People within the organization are often willing to take the time to speak with you and give you guidance. Very open door culture in that regard.
cons:
-I was never given any work to do and often sat there bored, when I asked for more work my emails/Instant messages were ignored. 
-Very few interns actually turn the internship into full-time work. We had a class of 45 interns or so and only 6 back office full time positions were posted online and they were all back office accounting positions. They tried to sell the Rotational Development Program (RDP) and many of us applied, however the tracks within the program that are even somewhat sought after, the Credit and Investments track, were filled by first and second year individuals who were already employed full-time at the firm. Barely any of us got a shot to learn a lot and to turn this into a full-time position. Correct me if I am wrong, but isn't that the point of an internship? 
-If you applied to multiple positions they will put you wherever you best fit their needs, not according to your performance or your preference. No consideration for the employee. 
-Very unorganized internship program
-Pay is not competitive to other organizations in financial services or public accounting
- Never really gave us any benefits or perks, I know other companies often provide lunch, t shirts, and other things to appreciate interns. We got like one lunch and a cheap coffee mug that broke before the end of the internship program. 
-Very high turnover rate, which is totally understandable. I interned there over the summer, (2 months ago) in my time there & via notifications on LinkedIn, i saw more than five employees already leave within the department I interned in. 
-There were so many students coming from top universities (Duke, Notre Dame, University of Chicago, Northwestern, Dartmouth, University of Michigan) and many of them in Asset Management and Wealth Management but they were no full-time positions for them. They were pretty much used for the sole purpose of cheap labor.
-A month after the program ended and I did not go for a full-time position, I got a call from a recruiter asking if I would like to apply for some of the roles that they did not fill. once again, USING PEOPLE FOR THEIR OWN BENEFITS.

headline: Relationship management
pros: Due to the fast changing financial environment there are many new opportunities. NT is a very entrepreneurial company always searching for new fitting solutions to complex investment problems investors encounter today.

cons: There are some people who like to float to their retirement, essentially becoming resistant to change and new methodologies.

headline: Below Market Salary Offer
pros: Average work environment. Some of the immediate managers or supervisors were nice to work with. Opportunities were presented on the horizon with future locations spoken about.
cons: The salary offers for the position were substandard in comparison to other companies as well as other locations, by an 8 to 10 thousand dollar difference according to some research sources. Some of the lower level executive leadership were awkward and very secretive and stand-offish and presented a non-inclusive work environment where it felt as though you had to be liked to advance as opposed to having a predictable performance path. HR seemed to be unorganized at best.

headline: Private Banker
pros: Company has a great legacy in the world of private banking and trust and investment management.  In Chicago (and Florida) the company has a strong foothold and name recognition.  In other markets private banking relationships are much more difficult to develop
cons: Company is very flat with relatively few offices which limits your ability to move up in the organization.  Most of the advancement has to occur in Chicago (the mothership) if you want to do something more than what you were hired for.  Unrealistic goals considering how restrictive underwriting and a conservative loan committee gives approvals driven by the size of the investment relationship, not the ability to service debt.

headline: I see Troubles Ahead
pros: Financial strong company with record profits year after year. Highly philanthropic in support of the communities.

My concern, is that the last round of cuts in May of 2016 hit MANY of the IT technical Subject Matter Experts (SME's) of many mission critical corporate operation systems leaving little of no one left who understand or can support those critical applications. I havea great respect for the company and would return if asked.

headline: Culture
pros: There are some very strong, high caliber and collaborative people.   Positive views of lateral movements to gain more experience, you don't just have to move up the management chain in one division to get recognized.   Strong firm that can execute (sometimes a bit slower than the rest).
cons: Very passive aggressive culture -- things that are said behind closed doors and in the "cliques" are more important than actual job performance and execution.   Long tenured resources have resulted in long memories - one misstep 20 years ago is more important than showing that you have learned and grown from the experience.  People development can at times only be encouraged / supported for those in the "cliques".

headline: Great for getting your foot in the door
pros:
- Widely respected company that provides professional growth and introduction to many industries (unfortunately that does not translate to good compensation)
- Employee training and on-boarding is very good and well organized
- Friendly work environment on most days
- Relatively low stress jobs in many departments
cons:
- Pay is significantly below market. Raises are rare and are not based on any merit. Bonuses are around 2-3 times lower than market average
- Technology is very old. There are many legacy applications that still are used which can cause operational issues. Investment in technology does not seem to be a management priority. When technology is developed, little to no on-boarding is done to ensure successful deployment. Very restrictive Outlook mailbox sizes just to save costs.
- Unusually high level of bureucracy, even for a large company. 
- High turnover, especially from young talent, in operational roles
- There are many redundant departments and middle managers that don't add any value to products
- Large operations groups are outsourced to India. This causes delays because many partners are not online during regular Central Time hours.

no focus on talent development and retention, that's the reason attrition is so high.

The company seems determined to pile on more and more contractors to fill in the gaps, but we're only allowed to keep them for 2 years, after which all that knowledge goes with them and we have to start training again with a new person.  Very short sighted.

headline: Unpaid & overworked. Elitist,out of touch management
pros: Generally nice people but some arrogant sobs, just like any other financial services co. Most areas are flexible with work-life issues.
cons: Pay & total compensation woefully low vs competitors.  Ineffective leadership/management. Wasteful spending on non-productive projects to stroke management egos. Management  brags about corporate giving to charities and pushes for employee engagement. Yet they continue making millions while effectively cutting employee pay while ramping up the workload and don't mention anything about what they are giving up. Elitist and out of touch!

headline: Let them eat cake!
pros: Focus on the client is the mantra. Service and the team spirit in achieving client satisfaction are paramount. A consensus, collaborative style in problem-solving. Tremendous resources devoted to brand management and the paternalistic cultural ethos.
cons: Adherence to a prudent, consensus management style keeps this Chicago trust company on the safe road --- and they prefer it that way. Expenses that exceed forecast are considered particularly abhorrent, and senior management doesn't hesitate to freeze pay or headcount to stay on track. The executive office has a tin ear for the effect this has on morale. In general, their communications betray a lack of understanding for how the "work gets done." Only recently has some serious funding been lent to the obviously crumbling technology infrastructure.

headline: Old Line Company and Culture
pros: Stable, well known company. Free checking and savings. Good learning experience. Nice to have on resume.
cons: Impacted by the artificially low interest rates and their operating margins are very small. Surprisingly not a good work / life balance in the Operations and Technology division. Most everyone dialed in from home several nights a week.

headline: A lot of talk, not much action
pros: Work/life balance options are generally very good. There are flex schedule and work from home options available to most employees. Benefits are generally good, although they have been scaled back recently. Very few companies offer a pension anymore, but Northern does.
cons: NT's management has only one focus - satisfying Wall Street. The only pervasive goal within the company is hitting ROI targets. There are plenty of platitudes and corporate sloganeering, but ultimately the company has no interest in excellence in anything. Keeping costs low is the primary driver throughout the company. This leads to behind-the-curve technology and poorly executed or unfinished projects. Employee engagement does not extend past a yearly survey and employee development is non-existent. The general solution to poor project performance is to add more layers of management rather than address resourcing problems or adjust approach to be more practical. Most of the values and slogans ring hollow.

headline: Senior Consultant
