headline: Clueless... and dangerously conservative mindset
pros:
As they have no clue about testing (system testing was a new concept to them) you'll look like a rock-star for the first few months as you explain the benefits of test requirements and system testing, auditability, and so on, as they listen to you with their mouths open in astonishment at this new heresy...

There are some genuine moments of comedy - such as project managers deciding that the best approach to testing is to get the new test team to author the functional specs, whilst the BAs author the test scripts from them and do the testing....
cons:
Company motto should be "If nothing else works, a total pig-headed unwillingness to look facts in the face will see us through".

Technologically and ideologically incompetent.  Most of the permanent staff are lifers and have never worked anywhere else, and have therefore no idea about other ways of working - and are too scared to try something different.

Useless at project management as an organisation.  The project managers are more concerned with their own inter-company 'networks' than actually delivering anything of quality.
No inclination to ever change their failing processes, even when clients are warning them that another occurrence of having to send the code back (when it won't execute, because they don't understand the concept of testing) to NT will result in loss of client.  A lot of this is born out of ignorance and arrogance.

There is a culture of blame.  Various teams are constantly at loggerheads over whose fault it is for either developing a system without first having the requirements, or waiting until a project is going critical and they 'borrow' resource from other teams in a desperate attempt to meet deadlines.

It's like the old Jasper Carrot joke about anthrax in pick 'n mix at Woolworths, in the respect that people are only bothered with their own job, and just ensuring that they pass their task on to the next person in the chain, regardless of the quality.

Avoid like the plague - there is nothing to enhance your career by working there.  You'll wonder how a large organisation can survive whilst being so inept at delivering IT, until you see the sheer volume of live defects and the very large off-shore team devoted to operating manual workarounds in live.

headline: Good company, good culture (Hedge Fund Services)
pros: Relatively flat org structure makes it way less cutthroat than other jobs. Everyone basically gets the same number of days off, with a slight bump for those that have been there a long time. I forget how many, but it seemed like a lot, so that was cool. Omnium/Citadel Solutions heritage is evident in the top-notch technology used. People are all very intelligent and willing to help other team members when needed. Basics of the job aren't tremendously difficult to master; sometimes there are more intricate issues, depending on the clients you're on (pretty standard). Totally decent work-life balance outside of busy season, which goes from January to mid-March. If you're counting at home, that's a full month less than a tax busy season... so, there's that!
cons: Relatively flat org structure offers less in terms of titled progression, if that's your thing. Some might find the monthly deliverables repetitive, but that also makes increases in efficiency more easily attainable. Last-minute client changes could mess up your dinner plans sometimes, but that's typical, right? If it seems like I'm tempering my criticisms... I guess I am!

headline: SVP
pros: Great company and great CEO.  Northern Trust is one of the best companies in the Chicago area to work for and Rick Waddell is the best CEO I have ever worked with in my career.  I have been at multiple financial companies and this is one company that really operates with integrity.
cons: Once you make it to the SVP level, there really is not much in terms of upward mobility.  In comparison to the larger banking companies, there just isn't as much career opportunities past the SVP level due to the size of the company.

headline: Fund Accountant
pros: The Fund Accounting department at Northern Trust is very diverse and has been growing rapidly in recent years.  This surge of the company toward becoming a global leader in fund administration and custodial services has resulted in a work environment that offers employees a great opportunity for internal movement.  A rotation around the many segments of Northern Trust's fund servicing sectors will lead you to learn volumes about different types of fund structures, investment trends, reporting and disclosure requirements, etc.  In summary, there is a lot to know in the world of Northern Trust fund accounting and it does take time and motivation to develop; nonetheless, a genuine dedication to your career and to your company will pay dividends at place like NT, which fuels itself off of a very strong internal network.
cons: The nature of a fund accounting job consists of a great deal of independent work. As a result, I strongly believe that it is important for the company to foster employee interaction.  Executive management once mentioned a goal of alleviating the isolation of different back office business units, but I think more could have been done to actually get the desired effect.

headline: Wealth Strategist
pros: The company enjoys a considerable reputation as a trusted firm for wealthy individuals which allows for both access and acceptance of sales presentations.
cons: The firm has massively under invested in technology for years.  I came here from Wells Fargo and cannot believe what a hindrance the technology is.  There is no centralized CRM or any other functioning data base.  Heaven help you if you utter a word about statement errors, pricing errors, lack of accessible information.  If one does so, they ate instantly branded a trouble maker.  We are required and heavily invented to push expensive proprietary investments even though all of them have underperformed their benchmarks for years.  I'm actively looking for a sales position in the financial services industry.  When I leave I'll just be one more in a long line of younger professionals who come and go like a revolving door.

headline: Investment Consultant
pros: Good work/life balance.  Nobody really works hard or long hours.  It's a great place to go if you're trying to work in financial services but not have to put in long hours. If you're at the end of your career and just trying to collect a paycheck this is a safe bet.
cons: The place thrives on mediocrity.  Politics control promotion and upward mobility.  Nobody leaves because people are well compensated compared to industry counterparts. Northern Trust is still run like a mom and pop bank.  The back-end IT infrastructure is somewhat antiquated and nobody is in a hurry to do anything.

headline: Safe and steady
pros:
Flexible working hours and location in selected departments.
Seems to be the best Custodian to work for.
Track record of integrity compared to other large financial institutions.

cons:
Every department is cut back to the bare bones in the quest to reduce costs.
Very little increase in pay and embarrassing bonus payments (if made).

headline: Private Equity Operations
pros:
Good Vacation Time
Steadily busy throughout the workday
Decent/Good transportation throughout the city (only until 6:30pm)
cons:
Most of the positive reviews were made by employees in other countries (IE: Bangalore), but I can honestly say the environment and moral of the Chicago offices is not a healthy one. 

Low salaries compared to industry standards. Bonuses are few and far between - as are raises. 

The employees are all in a rutt because of the current environment in which the company finds itself. The canal location is called "Canalcatraz" by the employees who work there because of it's likeness to a prison. The employees also have a prisoner mentality.

Culture of finger pointing and blame game among employees and management. Everyone is constantly trying to save their own behinds because of the cost cutting environment. 

Due to cost cutting environment people are fearful of making mistakes. Management is pressured to find more efficient and less costly ways to do things so employees are vulnerable to being let go. Because of this, employees are often on edge. Employee reviews are often done in a way as to not credit the employee enough so that they can be compensated better. 

They are in a cost cutting mode, and have been for the last 4 years. This means 0 raises for those in Operations or the other entry level areas. Bonuses are often just $500 - hey better than nothing, right?

Hardly any room for growth, and even if there is a position available the compensation is hardly any better. 

Because they are in a cost cutting mode, there are hardly any amenities. The company nickel and dimes their employees. The gym costs $40/month, which is more expensive than most of the other gyms in the area. Often times a company's gym is free to their employees. Sometimes employees health care costs are lessened if they use the company gym. Not at Northern. It costs $40/month.

Must pay for coffee as well (i realize this really isn't a con) but the fact that employees are sometimes discouraged/questioned when getting coffee. The coffee is stationed on 1 floor, and people are often questioned as to why they are always leaving to go get it.  

There is lots of turnover among employees. Employees try to leave their position after a year is up because they find themselves doing something they hate - or at least working in an environment that they hate.

People constantly going to HR. IMPORTANT: HR is always there to protect the company - not the employee. Wrongful terminations. One guy was fired because his manager in Private Equity Operations did not like him or his attitude of just showing up to do his work and not make friends with manager or most of employees. Guy wasn't a bad guy, just had his friends and made it a point to be standoffish to others. 

High turnover among management. 4 different managers same department n(actually in several depts) in last 4 years. 

Favoritism among managers and employees of same race. Obviously this is a pretty serious allegation, and it is just that. It's very hard to be proven so you would just have to take a stranger's word for it on the internet. Many employees would complain about how managers of certain colors allow the employees of those colors to get away with being unprofessional or other things.  

Employees are over worked, and everyone has a miserable attitude because of it. Constantly putting more work on employees and not compensating them for it. 

The IT systems are outdated and constantly crashing. This makes for a more stressful day for some because time frames and cut off times are in place and the work needs to be done using manual systems or far outdated systems. If the work is needed by another department whose systems are working fine there is added pressure. When this happens every other week and improvements aren't made by higher ups, this is an issue. Employees end up in more of a rut.

headline: Product Manager
pros: All in all a good experience.  Some areas are great to work in while others are not, so it is all about finding your niche.  There is opportunity for advancement if you seek it and work hard.  Most coworkers are friendly.  Upper management is fairly accessible if you are in Chicago. 4 weeks paid vacation.  Decent benefits.  Most areas you can wfh two days a month or so.
cons: Pay is not great.  Since the crash it has been about efficiency/productivity so work loads have increased and staff levels have reduced which has made morale a little lower.  Some areas are not as nice to work in as others.  Almost like working for a different company.

headline: Personal Banking Investigator (Auditor)
pros: I really enjoy the people I worked with. I had an awesome partner and met some really nice people in other departments that were helpful and knowledgeable.
cons: The pay is way below what it should be for the workload and responsibilities. The management also treats those who are not at management level as less than and with blatant disrespect. Countless incidents of being spoken down too even when I was right. It is also very hard to move around in the company without heavy networking. Promotions are based on who you know rather than what you know.

headline: Dissapointing Experience this company is way over rated, no thanks, pass that kool aid to the next cult member
pros: NONE. If you are lazy and lack technical skills, this place is for you. Full of silly politics from non talented individuals who think they are stars. Form over substance types apply here you will do well, actual proven stars need not waste their time here, if you don't conform to your boss's inefficient ways, they will retaliate with termination or if your lucky a demotion. I ran out of space on Cons, so for the reader, a bit of clarification. Pros for lazy untalented individuals who want to get by with only knowing the right people. Forget about having communication or public speaking skills, or real accounting tech skills or knowledge, no just show up if you already know somebody here, and you can coast and be a yes man , you will get a promotion. If you have no clue about fund accounting, have no fear, your free pass is automatic here as long as you know the right people, and I am not exaggerating here. They like to terminate people for no reason before  6 months ,who they may not like due to people trying to make things more efficient, no do not do that here, you must drink the kool aid and be a total follower of mediocrity. If you think a Credit Default Swap only has one leg, just because its more convenient to just reflect the Periodic fixed premium stream that the Buyer Leg pays for protection to the Seller Leg ( since the Seller leg only pays out in the event of a credit event or default of the underlying fixed income security , and its easier to not represent a contingent payout event in the system) instead of the correct answer two legs, simply because every swap has two legs Swap 101 basics,  then you belong here. If you do not understand how to be efficient with using sunguard macros in conjunction with red flag exception systems and the accounting system, then you belong here. If you think doing recons on micro soft excel spreadsheets are faster than one click macro oles that can be set up via Sunguard connections, and help you with a real time analysis, then you belong here. It perplexed me that they would prefer slower methods of getting work done when the fund accounting environment is always loaded with various deadlines daily, so fast is essential.
cons: I went to a managers meeting at Northern Trust my first month there, and I must say it actually felt like I stepped into some "CULT" like pass me the kool aid event where some lady from HR was at the podium in some Preachy style of presentation to the crowd of managers from various different lines of business. I also observed the culture there more in depth where the "suits" from the other office would have these presentations that sounded more like info mercials of motivation. Bottomline, this place wreaks of Form over Substance, if you are lazy , and like to talk a good talk, and rely on keep your job via knowing the right people as opposed to performance on the job and team collaboration, this place is for you. There is a trend here of others pointing out that hey so and so is a "superstar" too frequently without that so called super star actually proving that are the real deal. As I said form over substance, its a clique thing purely here, and if you are an outsider, no matter how experienced or good you are , they will not give you credt. They will only prop up their happy hour buddies or weekend buddies from work as "superstars". Its amusing, seeing people proclaim others or themselves as "stars" before actually proving it via performance. Finally, if you come from a collaborative environment where ideas and input are welcome from all team members without worrying about retaliation, well this place is not that. You have to conform to a cult like fashion, and if you variate or try to help with a more efficient way of doing things, they retaliate with politics, to demotions, to even termination without a reason. Not a healthy place for true superstars to contribute to the team goals, it's all conformity here. They like talking a good talk here, but execution is not efficient, and they do not grasp being efficient or working smarter instead of mediocre harder methods.

Varies a lot depending on departments. Most of the people I've networked with are actively looking to leave due to the low pay.

headline: Northern Trust Melbourne
pros:
Stable career to do similar daily workflow
Large US brand
Friendly working culture
cons:
US-centric, not willing to invest/build local talents
Over-reliant on offshore support team who delivers poor quality. Management only focus on cost-saving, not quality delivery.
No career progression.
Inflexible system with offshore IT follow-up provide limited focus. 
Conflict of interest between departments to protect self-interest instead of client interest.
Culture of no rewards for additional client wins. 
Inconsistent local firm policies as opposed to firm's global policies while managers make changes outside the handbook at their discretion.
Unnecessary bureaucracy that increase complexity within the organisational structure creating multiple level of free-loaders.
Incompetent management team with no appreciation of professional skills. They hire over-qualified people to do monkey work at peanut pay.
Business revenue often under-quote to win business for sale's team purpose while bottom-line often in the red at the expense of the firm and thus staff's compensation. 
Innovative ideas gets shut-down therefore using out-dated systems and process workflow.
Fancy external hire and next to no chance for internal promotions.

headline: Vice President
pros: Global custodian with foot print around the world.  Open to operating in many countries.  Product offerings are a mile wide.
cons: Compensation.  Northern consistently places the burden of reduces expenses on the backs of employees.  While in a low, tight interest rate environment, Northern placed, and rightly so, a very high priority on reducing costs.  However, because by far the greatest costs at Northern are compensation and benefits, the only way to significantly reduce costs was through lowering growth in salaries/bonuses and reducing benefits which Northern has done.  As a result, morale is probably at an all time low.

headline: Employees Are Not Valued
pros: There is a pension plan.
cons: Even though 2014 was an excellent year for the company's earnings, most employees didn't get a raise. The only employees who seem to like working for this company are the employees who've worked for Northern Trust their entire careers, and they manage, and are managed, by fear. Everyone else is surviving until they can move on. There's virtually no opportunity for growth, advancement or promotion for most employees, and the hiring practices have gone downmarket to save money. Most new hires are right out of college, or a few years out of college, and not too bright.

headline: Run, do not walk, away!

This even includes functions that may not be legally outsourced, but in the name of bringing down costs and despite high profitability, it continues.  Entire departments have been wiped out and the work sent to India. Good senior people are gone, and they have been replaced with people who have no background in the financial services industry but who are cost cutters.

headline: Don't Get Sucked In
pros: Three weeks vacation to start, higher pay at entry level (though it remains stagnant at that point).
cons: Middle management is unprofessional and, frankly, unkind.  I witnessed my manager scream at an an employee while slamming her hand on a counter.  This type of behavior was encouraged.  Company rarely promotes from within.  Employees tend to feel more fearful for their jobs than happy to be there.  On a whim, management would move employees to other locations.  In the time I was there, I was moved 6 times between 4 locations even though my manager knew I had moved to be closer to the original office.  I came with 10 years of banking experience and once I saw how poorly retail banking was run, I began applying for other positions.  No one even considered me.

headline: review
pros: good and flexible to work
cons: less pay..since cost of living is high

headline: Fair
pros: If you worked hard, it was recognized and rewarded.
cons: Compensation was lower than average. It was normal for employees to quit Northern and come back years later to obtain a higher salary.

headline: Good client-focused company.
pros: Fair, good benefits. Consistent company to work for.
cons: Limited opportunities/job challenges. Over- utilizing some and not utilizing others.

headline: Not what it used to be
pros: Work/life balance is a solid positive. Management at the line is talented and generally supportive of employees.
cons:
The organization claims to value the employee population but senior management actions are not supportive of the words. Workforce is too lean for demand and with multiple cuts over the past few years, the load has only increased. Many employees are either riding out their time to retirement or have generally lost their commitment to the organization. 
Finally, there is not a consistent vision from the top to the bottom. The vision and action plans do not filter completely through to the delivery teams.

headline: Good 1st Job
pros: Train you well, there is room to move up, team work. It is a great 1st job to get your foot in the door to start your careet.
cons: Pay is low, work life balance is hard, periods of extremely high stress. Fund accounting is BORING! It is also extremely niche.

headline: Very poor environment for hard working, driven people
pros: Job security is not a problem. They won't fire anybody for any reason
cons: Bonuses, raises, advancements are not based on merit. All depends on how long you have been there.

headline: Good company, good opportunities
pros: Good opportunities for family people or those that are good "people people" and can easily build relationships.  Hours are consistent.
cons: Relationship building can be challenging.  Can be slow to implement "standard technology".

headline: Conservative Financial Services Company
pros:
- Great work-life balance
- Company is risk averse/conservative
- Pension plan
- Hardworking people
- Strong & easy going culture/history
cons:
- Hard to move up, promotions are hard to come by
- Outdated tech
- Benefits are OK
- Tend to hire people with a lot of experience/overqualified
- Compensation could be better

headline: Good place to work
pros: Some really nice people work there, and some of them really know their stuff.  They have a lot of technology projects, and bright people at the top running them.  They're a major market maker and a very reputable old Chicago institution.  Some people have been there for decades.
cons: The organization is a bit bureaucratic, so things take time to get approval.  It seems, some people do about 30 minutes of real work every other day.  Others work unpaid overtime to pick up the slack.  Agressive offshore recruiting onsite derails many a project.  They have some pretty old tech there and need to cut the cord.

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Managers are very supportive.  Very much work-life oriented company. Training and growth are very much encouraged.
cons: I would need to investigate further as to whether or not I'm paid fairly.  I don't think that they have annual salary increased any longer, unless you have a major expectation change.

headline: Stuck in the 1970's
pros: Fairly predictable and easy work, easy hours
cons: consultants not treated as equitable to employees

headline: Stay Away !
pros: Absolutely none. Northern Trust is a place for people who just do not care.
cons: Salaries across the company, Room for advancement, Politics, ZERO TALENT !

headline: Very stable company and great place to start your career.
pros: I started working here straight out of college . It was a great company to begin my career to gain experience . The great thing about this company is the stability . Job security has never been an issue in the 8 years I've worked here. The company encourages movement within the company and reaching out to partners for informationals is only an email away. You can find executives to mentor your career and help guide you in development.
cons: The salary has got to be the most frustrating thing about this company. The initial hiring will bring you in based off market standard rates , but once in the company it's difficult to get any market adjustments. The yearly increase is very minimal , I've seen as low as 0- 1,000 increase in base salary. This is very frustrating as it does not help encourage a partner to feel appreciated and want to give their all. I've been told that my salary is indeed below market value and my manager would try to request some form of increase but not to get my hopes up. Hearing your manager acknowledge you're being undervalued and unappreciated but telling you that there may not be anything we can do about it is very frustrating.

headline: Senior Analyst
pros:
Good working environment.
Managers are very helpful and approachable.
Good training provided as a new employee.
cons: The company has no drawbacks.

headline: The overall experience was good.
pros: Its probably the best company for a fresher to start his/her career, the culture is very good, the HR plays a very important role in the company which helps any employee from being treated badly.
cons: The work life balance sucks in most of the process, I personally had worked for nearly 22 hours sometimes. The management decisions  are not up to the mark. There are internal politics which sometimes prevents a person from growing in the organization.

headline: Easygoing, low stress, low pay
pros: Working at Northern has great work/life balance. Hours are easy, coworkers are nice.
cons: The company is slow to invest I'm technology and its employees. Low interest rates adversely impact employee comp.

headline: Great Company, Less Compensation
pros: They pamper you with diverse culture and freedom. Less pressure and definitely for people with long term goals.
cons: Compensation is not up to the mark, being stuck in one process for long, career development on the slow track.

headline: Great Work Culture, usual politics, matured stage causing slow growth
pros:
Work Culture is good.
Lot to learn or else you can do the work and get over with it, depends on the approach, both are acceptable.
Good place if you are joining as a manager.
cons:
Pay is bad and so is the annual hike and bonus.
Politics is usual and managers keep playing with people to find new ways to prove something or the other.

headline: People friendly company. Work not that great.
pros:
people driven
less stress
ideal for women
cons: you cannot utilise your potential as it is an outsourced industry

headline: Good company to start with
pros: Company has good learning and development opportunities, good training faculty
cons: lack of transparency in the development by management

headline: The Gold Standard
pros: Excellent working environment.  Wholesome climate.  Corporate culture built on strong ethics and placing the client's best interests first. Excellent professional resources. Top tier clients. Intelligent,  hard-working colleagues. Great benefits, lots of vacation time.
cons: Below average salaries, above average work load. Struggles with technology. Bureaucratic.

headline: "Overall a decent place to work"
pros:
1) Stability
2) Learning
3) Engaging with management.
cons: Nothing much but they dont retain good employee's. No place for aggresive (in good sence) people.

headline: Great Work Life Balance
pros: Standard work hours great for working moms.
cons: Management needs to move to the nursing homes that await them. No innovation whatsoever at this organization. Get ready to push paper.

headline: The worst place to work in technology
pros: There are no benefits whatsoever to working at Northern Trust.  It is the absolute worst place to work if you are in technology.
cons:
This is the worst job I've ever had in my 25+ year career in technology.

Northern has a one-size-fits-all mentality when solving problems.  If the solution does not meet their predefined process, it cannot be implemented.

The ability to work efficiently is impeded by strict adherence to PROCESS instead of intelligence and common sense.  The drive for quality is undermined by over-reliance on cheap offshore labor that produces sub standard work product, much of which must be redone.

headline: It was a good company, worked at the Canal Building. Wish I was learning more. Mostly administrative work.
pros: Great benefits, good salary, good entry level job for college graduate. This is a great Chicago company and offers many opportunities for growth within the company.
cons: Poor training. It felt like I had to learn everything myself, which is not terrible, but when there are deadlines to be met and you are given most the work, it is hard to keep up and maintain a steady work pace, while minimizing errors.

headline: good place to a fresher easy to get in hard to grow
pros: easy entrance n 3 weeks of leaves
cons:
pathetic level of growth,less work, less challenge less growth
pathetic women supporting policy resembles like a very gender biased place where who expects women for taking rest and dominating men using the company's policies given to respect and protect them..

headline: Great company to work for!
pros: Great people to work with. Exciting environment.
cons: Hard to move up the ladder.

headline: overview
pros:
great work life balance

a lot of time off

steady pay

employees are likable and usually easy going
cons: pay is on the cheaper side

headline: Very good experience
pros: Strong culture; great benefits, including pension
cons: Difficult to make vertical moves; always lateral

headline: Stay Away
pros: Good people to work with
cons: No funding for work,lots of lay offs, poorly managed

headline: Wealth Management
pros:
- Excellent reputation 
- Top-tier client base
- Best work/life balance in the industry (at least in Wealth Management)
- Opportunities to move within firm 
- Everyone is approachable and networking is appreciated
- Many career related perks - mentors, education assistance, ability to seize opportunities around firm, etc.
- I personally work on the investment management team and can say almost all of my colleagues are well educated, intelligent, & hard-working
cons:
- Can be competitive internally but expected in an investment management environment
- The firm as a whole can be somewhat slow to adopting new/contemporary methodologies
- Pay is average in most departments however this can be avoided if you make worthwhile career-moves
- Pressure to get advanced degrees/certification (may be a negative for some)
- Firm-wide communication is adequate but can be improved upon

headline: Good experience
pros: Northern trust has a well established business model and reputation. Working for this company allows you to develop business skills applicable to any Fortune 500 company.
cons: large age gap, paid under market value, change management needs improvement

headline: Northern Trust Hedge Fund Services: Manager
author_position: Northern Trust Hedge Fund Services: Manager
pros: Middle managers are given a great deal of responsibility and the opportunity to have a material impact on the entire division. Northern Trust benefits are competitive.
cons:
Company sells guarantees to clients that the company is not equipped to deliver. Further, they do not provide the resources or support to implement long term solutions. Upper management is relatively disconnected from middle management and staff, and the only transparency they have of the business is that which is pushed to them from the lower level. Management seems genuinely unconcerned with the shortfalls of the business and tends to only be reactive in strategy. 

Certain teams work low hours and low stress while others are stretched entirely too thin. Compensation starts out competitive, but you will never make big jumps internally.

headline: Great place to start out your career - but don't stay long.  They don't give pay raises or compensate well.
pros: Nice work/life balance.  Good place to start when you are right out of college.
cons: Poorly compensated. No career growth, no leadership. A good place to start when you are younger, but do not stay long.

headline: I have Worked for Northern Trust (Bangalore) Office
pros:
Very Good Company to Start off with,Good Salary, Open Door Policy, Very Supportive Management, Employee Oriented. Good Company for Lady Employees. Good Team Members.

If I get a chance to work again. I would definitely take it up.
cons: Night Shift, Work Load still can be managed and Politics in few departments which can ruin the company

headline: No Work life banace
pros: 1. Nothing, if you really want to grow this is not your company. If you love gossips then you are welcome
cons:
1. Manager ask for overtime almost every day but will not let you fill time sheets
2. They will call you on all public holidays india / US / UK forget  rule, which client you are working.
3. They will call you on election day also which should be holiday in india as per govt but they dont care.
4. Very minimal salary hike , TCS have better salary hikes than these guys.
5. They will call you on new year for 2 hours only to avoid giving you comp offs.
6. Cabs , why you are offering when you cant manage. Some one who live 5kms away take 30 mins in worst traffic will get picked 1 and half hour before.
7. None of drivers have edicate to talk to lady employees and complain against them doesn't reach to right person.
8. On 150th anniversary company gave some cheap refreshment  in costly boxes. Whom you are making fool?

headline: Work Life at Northern
pros: Very Hood Learning, Work-Life Balance, Well Work Allocation, Minimum Overtime, Helpful offshore partner
cons: More than knowledge tenure is preached does not matter how efficient the partner is.

headline: Investment Operations Outsourcing
pros: The company has a great middle office department, which handles back office operations tasks. The team is supported by excellent management knowledgeable partners. IT provides an excellent learning environment for new college grads.
cons: There are very limited opportunities to advance in back office operations. Though it is a great foot in the door to move onto other roles within the organization.

headline: Great Experience
pros: Professional and Helpful management. Great first job after degree.
cons: Cannot think of any at this time.

headline: Good stable job, good culture, little growth opportunity
pros: corporate culture is positive, family oriented, safe/stable job, benefits are decent
cons: Very few people get pay raises, only way to move up is to entirely change jobs.

headline: They act like a bank that is 125 years old.

Company does not retain good employees or employees that know the work.  It is hard to move within the bank.  There is no career advancement for the good employees since people advance based on political connections.

headline: Excellent   company

In order to be promoted you have to leave to another department, or leave the bank and come back to a higher role

headline: Great place
pros: Good salary/good benefits/ good work environment/good managers

headline: Great place
pros: Young Crowd and best place where employee is greatly respected
cons: Shift Timings are a bit of an issue for a few people

headline: Good Company, but bad bad growth prospects
pros: Decent work -life balance, good work environment and a good salary for a start...
cons: Bad growth prospects and growth is minimal..... somehow hate giving promotions and thats how many good employees look for other opportunities elsewhere..

headline: Not a good experience
pros: Work environment  is good, very good people around, best for the freshers and those who are interested in curricular activity.
cons:
I saw a very biased managers , promotions based on how well you please management than your performance .Growth is too bad , no work life balance even though they say there is work life balance .

May be good place for some and may not be for others, people will be punished  for voicing the concern

headline: Good Place but lacks identity
pros: Great people, well respected in industry, nice to have on resume.  Allows for a work life balance and is relatively employee friendly.
cons: I was in the investment management side and we completely lacked an identity.  Compensation is somewhat low relative to the industry and this has hurt.  Company is not sure what they want to be - indexer, active, manager of manger.

headline: Awful
pros:
- It's next to impossible to get fired.
- If you're already established, low output requirements for decent pay
cons:
- Low pay for young people
- Low mobility
- Hypocritical pay for management
- If you start low, it takes years of "market adjustments" to get you where you should be (raises capped at 10% of current pay, even if you're below market)

headline: Very good opportunities as a recent Graduate. Well known company that opens up opportunities with a lot of other firms
pros: Very good work/life balance; you get bank holidays off as well as very generous time off/sick days/personal days/work from home opportunities.Well known company that opens up opportunities with a lot of other firms within the financial services industry.
cons: Can get very boring with the monotonous work; You do the same things week in and week out. Depending on where you are, there is no real on-boarding training sessions... you get dropped in and are expected to know what you're doing.

headline: I have learnt a lot during my tenure here at NT and I have been able to learn the wider scope of the out sourcing busine
pros:
NT provides end to end services to Investment Managers and it goes beyond trade processing and settlement.
I have learnt  about performance and valuation reporting, pricing, asset coding, client service reviews etc
I work with Senior Executives at the Asset Managers as well as other levels of people within varaious organizations.
cons: It is a challenge working with the shared services who are located overseas and my observation has been since they are further away from issues, they do not understand the urgency of issues.

headline: Investment Systems Summer Intern
pros:
More laid back culture and dress at the Canal building
Friendly people -- biggest pro
Stable company with good leadership
cons:
monotonous work
very traditional
growth prospects are mediocre
no commitment towards learning

headline: Lack of investment in new hires
pros: Nice name on your resume.
cons:
It is hard to be successful at a job you were hired to do when the first two weeks on the job there was no training at all. The two days of training they provide is very poor and basic. If you can't get by on those two days, your manager contacts HR and alerts them they hired the wrong person.

IT does a terrible job granting access to the software programs you need to do your job. It took me a month before I was given a phone number and it took a week to get a email address.

headline: Overworked
pros: Will learn a lot (obviously)
cons: But nothing no other accountant knows.  Underpaid

headline: Overall it is good but hardwork and technical knowledge is not recognized at all by the Manager
pros: Global exposure, work life balance,
cons: Team members are not experienced but joining at the senior level

headline: Consultant
pros: Great colleagues and networking opportunities
cons: Management doesn't always support career growth or involvement in networking opportunities

headline: An organization with potential...
pros: For the most part, the people (or partners, as they call them) are hard-working, conscientious and very approachable.  The level of intelligence is high and the knowledge of the industry - be it investment management, credit analysis and underwriting, and estate planning - is as good as it gets.  Benefits are solid and the work/life balance issue is good, though producers may find that the amount of time required to get the deals done can require operating on CST...meaning 6:00am credit presentations.
cons: Personal growth is a pure function of revenue generated.  If you want to remain in the good graces of management, year over year revenue growth is mandatory, regardless of the business cycle.  Also, as the Chicago market is fully saturated and can barely support single-digit revenue growth, the expectation is for California to be the driver of revenue and bottom-line growth.  However, a disproportionate level of the retained earnings continues to be invested in the Chicago region which, in my book, does not support a forward-thinking rationale.  Keep in mind that what works in the Midway doesn't necessarily work on the West Coast.  There's a reason why people live here.  Understand the differences and orchestrate the business model to cater to that mindset.

headline: Chicago HQ did not support Northern California in terms of resources to expand relationships.
pros: Bank has a long history of custody and investment management services, beginning in 1889.  Company values work-life balance and confidentiality of client business.
cons: Employees do not receive good training so reliance was based upon prior experience only.  Resources to expand in selected regions outside of Chicago were not available.  Expansion of target markets was taken only after years of research.  Chicago HQ did not value relationship banking and did not provide resources, both dollars and technology to support growth.

headline: Exchange Traded Funds Analyst
pros: Great people, great atmosphere, great teamwork, mutual feedback
cons: Sticklers on time, strict dress code

headline: I was hired to do a specific job, but when I refused to compromise on the principles I was told to uphold, I was demoted
pros: Benefits are well above average.
cons: There are two tribes at this company. The Brotherhood is the power tribe. Very WASPY. Everyone else belongs to the underclass, and is treated accordingly.

headline: My first job and made me feel as best job
pros:
Amazing working environment, so much fun with so much learning. 
They recognise the talent n efforts of partner by giving awards with monetary benifits.
cons: Few managers are very biased.

headline: Overall a great company to work for!
pros: The benefits are pretty good.  Opportunities to grow if you really want it.  They offer a lot of cross-training and encourage employees to move around to other positions to grow. Work/life balance is good.
cons: Need to stop outsourcing.  Some days you feel like your department will be up and gone in no time.

headline: Good place to start career for UGs
pros:
Get to work on good processes
Good people
Good leave policies
Good Work environment
cons:
Not a place for PG freshers
Work experience is not directly related to promotions

headline: Kind of boring considering the amount of money being processed.
pros: Conservative and safe company to work for.

Decent health benefits and vacation.

headline: Employee friendly....

cons: CEO needs to be more strategic and seems to be playing catch up with the realities of the economy and industry.

headline: Many of the very good and supportive managers don't exist anymore.
pros: Family work life balance and training provided.
cons: Too many layers of management and unhappy workers within operations.  Even management is unhappy and not great leaders. Many displays of favoritism and limited career growth to utilize education and work experience. Management only take cares of their favorite people and opportunities are not fairly given to each employee.

cons: long hours and we have to work even holidays

headline: Great culture, support, opportunity if you're willing to move

cons: Pay, promotion within business unit

headline: Great company with incredible potential.
pros: Potential for growth (Company and Individual), Work-Life balance, Pension, Career Opportunities
cons: Very slow decision making, Mid level management lacking tactics, Salary not in par with the market.

headline: Could be better but its not
pros: benefits are good but when you have no money to go places its irrelevant
cons: pay can be much better- better off leaving NT then coming back

headline: Good place with great people
pros:
Networking opportunities with upper management (even for entry-level employees).
Everyone here is very willing to help out. 
Nice work/life balance.
cons: Nothing that really stands out.

headline: Performance gets rewarded
pros: work culture, work-life balance, learning
cons: for me all good till date

headline: Ok can be better
pros: Global mobility, flexible working conditions, benefits such as health cover and pension
cons: Desicion making can be hierarchical, low salary

headline: Decent Experience/Great First Career Step
pros: Northern Trust carries strong reputation among SuperRegional Banks, and has been around for quite some time.  As a first career, any entry level position is a step up on your resume.  Benefits are great, and salary is manageable.
cons: Salary isn't something that's a strong point here, seems like all entry level positions are atleast 10% under the market norm.  Management has too many similar roles paying VP's and Sr VP's to do Consultant/TC roles.  The TL position is supposed to carry management duties, however most are overriden by the Team Manager, so role is basically a TC without overtime.

headline: Stable and Neutral.
pros: Culture, Work-Life Balance, Intelligent Colleague. Always opportunities. Great if you are more seasoned in your career and have family responsibilities. Stable.
cons: Compensation. It's common knowledge that Northern pays ~20% below market rate when it comes to salary (No matter what the position). HR will pitch "work life balance" and "culture", which is all well and good; but if you are young, motivated, and looking to earn a wage commensurate with your work product, Northern is not the place. On more than 1 occasion I have had well respected managers advise that "You are better off working here for a year/two, leave to make your money elsewhere and then come back". That certainly is discouraging when overall it is a great place to work.

headline: Great Culture
pros: Pay is competitive, SME skillset, great working environment
cons: promotions seem to be siloed

headline: So far so good. Big, reliable, safe bank.
pros: culture and peple are great
cons: Compensation is not the best

headline: Overall
pros: Job security is good here
cons: Salary is low and compensation is horrible

headline: Great Place to Work
pros:
Great people
Great Pay
Great City
Lots of opportunity
Great fun
cons: No cons that I can think of.

headline: Frustrating
pros: Stability, Opportunity for some, time-off for some
cons: Company rewards the wrong people in my experience, management, pay, poor training

headline: Sr. Consultant
pros: Stable company and very conservative views.
cons: Middle management is terrible in that they don't underastandf the ole of the teams they are overseeing.  They aren't expected to know the job just manage people.

headline: Right place, wrong century.
pros: Nice people, highly moral organization, great community involvement, people happy to mentor, many long tenured employees.
cons: Two classes of employees, those that have been around 20+ years and everyone else.  Non-competitive from a comp standpoint, very average benefits and continuously getting less generous. Been in a cost cutting mode for years, especially in areas like banking and traditional custody business. Very set in its ways, constant movement of senior management means nobody is in a position long enough to be measured or accountable. Log jam of long tenured people in management makes it almost impossible to move up in certain areas of the bank. Many of the employees have given up trying, they simply do the minimum required and the organization seems ok with it. People aren't honest, not because they are liars but because they don't want to hurt feelings or upset anyone.

headline: Great people, great environment, could use some modernizing
pros: Incredibly helpful coworkers and superiors
cons: Technology and office perks are way outdated

headline: Good company, great culture, great work/life balance
pros: Good work/life balance, strong leadership, great company values
cons: Conservative culture, slow growth relative to peers

headline: Good place to start with...
pros:
Great culture.
Good learning and training.
Employee focused.
Good opportunities to grow.
cons:
Some times over time. It depends in which team you are in. not in all teams.
Growth opportunities varies across departments so you might need to move to another team to grow but that s fine if you are able to grow.
Low Bonus. Really Bad.
Less pay.

headline: Stable with no career progression

Stable career doing similar work day-in and day-out
Recognized global brand

cons:
Lack of career progression
Incompetent local management outside US
Lack of support from Bangalore in Middle Office despite years of effort to embrace their failures to improve

Disproportionate benefits

headline: Good for progress, poor for benefits (Lux office)

cons: Compensation package not competitive, promotion with little or no salary increase, very long to recruit which often put people in place under pressure, little recognition of work done, no career opportunities for insiders but a lot for outsiders.

headline: A sturdy company
pros: Many departments (but not all) have good work-life balance, and give the employees leeway to work from home and use their available time as they wish.
cons: There are a lot of people who leave Northern Trust so they can return to Northern Trust.  This is because Northern Trust will pay more for an external candidate than for someone within the system.

headline: worked for two years in fund of hedge fund process
pros: work culture and atmosphere was good
cons: workload was too much at times

headline: Struggling and failing to adapt
pros: Work-life balance, not very demanding, ancient computer systems are finally starting to be addressed, good reputation even though it's based on staying out of trouble which is easy to do if you don't do much
cons: Terrible management - just had another round of musical chairs guaranteeing that they don't know how to do their jobs, coasting on past, extremely political, expect to grow sales while cutting staff, no opportunity for advancement, low comp relative to the market and getting worse

headline: Good experience. The atmosphere has bee the best sice I started my career.
pros: Workinf hours 9-5, so good work life balance. The atmosphere there is great. No micromanagement at all. You feel good there after working in super big corporations
cons: Northern trust didnt cut work force when the crisis hit so they are doing that now. Lots of work is transferred to India  of Ireland so there was no work for me any more, I totally understand their decision to do this. its so much cheaper to hire people in India.

headline: Awash in a sea of mediocrity and middle-management
pros: For the most part a very employee-friendly company.  Good benefits and for the most part, very friendly people.  Great place to work if you enjoy predictability, and are okay with slow growth.
cons: The friendly atmosphere lends itself to slow-moving processes and an endless array of bureaucracy.  If you are an aggressive, money-motivated financial sales professional, there are better places for you.

headline: Very fast paced environment.  Lots of work
pros: Management is open to training.

headline: Nice people, conservative bank, good place to work
pros:
Colleagues were very approachable and helpful; I still keep in touch with some.
Good experience working with large clients.
Ability to find other opportunities within the firm is good.
cons:
Pay is not commensurate with work.
It is difficult to be removed from your position; and some should. This created an attitude of complacency among some employees and the quality of work suffered.

headline: Highly Underappreciated and Severely Underpaid Employees
pros: - 4 weeks of vacation
cons:
- Accountants are pushed to a building on the South side of the Loop and are not in banking buildings. Not a "One" group feel.
- Cheap on pay with it's "Partners" - well below industry standards
- VPs are removed from the work their staff and seniors are performing and unrealistic about time lines internal due dates.
- Salaried individuals are not given any recognition when overtime is put in and it's excessive during busy periods. 
-  VPs unable to think outside the box and do not meet industry standard practices
- Lack of a sense of teaming due  to the VP frowning on communication- people do not talk to each other even though they are working in the same group and on the same project people. 
- Company Policies are not followed in each department and apply to ONLY certain.
- Unreasonable expectations and lack of resources creates unnecessary overtime for all 
- Redundancy in the work to create job security as I quote direct from the VP
- Lack of effective work-life balance despite the fact that Northern says they promote the issue.
- Cheap budget meaning the resources you do have are inefficient and dated for tax return preparation and tax research.
- Preferential treatment provided to certain individuals who have been with the department longer. 
-Expectations that if you are the new person you are given the shaft when it comes to office coverage and pto during holidays and during non-busy season.
- Honesty in this department is not a given.
- Professionalism is not a priority within the group I was in and really was almost embarrassing to clients.
-Low budget so raises are not within industry standards and limit earning potential. This also translates into no holiday parties or company outings. 
- Lack of communication from top down approach - ie 400 people will be let go in 2014 and 2015 was announced in Crain's Mag before even being communicating it to their own employees.
Overall the group I worked in I felt was less than acceptable when it came to professionalism which really in the end created a hostile working environment. I would say that anyone considering working for this company take a serious look elsewhere before signing any employment contract with them.

headline: Northern Trust review
pros:
Good work life balance
Friendly working environment
Northern Trust focus on more people engagent
cons: IT/ System applications are not updated

headline: Good place to work

headline: very satisfied with the company's culture a good company to be associated with.

cons: hard to mention any out of my experience

headline: Good company to work

cons: Pay is pretty less for freshers, but eventually you will climb the ladder and will get good benefits. Less meetings

headline: Trust Management
pros: Solid firm with long term focus. Employees are valued and Northern Trust has comprehensive benefits and coverages for all employees
cons: Not always able to make decisions as quickly or transparently as would be liked by those on the front lines.

headline: Senior Analyst
pros: the work culture in Northern is very good
cons: As usual internal politics in some teams

headline: Good Atmosphere
pros: Company is much less stressful than retail banks. Offers a decent salary. Branches are closed on Saturdays! People are nice. Good PTO.
cons: Technology is out dated. Very conservative company. No bonuses.

headline: Sr. Software consultant in IT
pros: Great company in Chicago for IT department. Employees are very happy with work and life balance. Flexible work schedule.
cons: Some technologies are not properly utilized. But we see changes now.

headline: Rec and Control. Awful group. Awful hours. Get in your silo and keep your mouth shut.
pros: Compensation is decent based on industry standards.  The insurance benefits are decent but still run $500 for family BCBS.  Training is available, if you ever have a desire to spend time at work beyond the 10-12 hour work days.  Good opportunity if you're looking to add a high volume administrator to your professional experience.
cons: Hedge Fund Services has carried on Citadel's work culture.   If you're not Citadel / Omnium legacy, your chances of inner-department promotion are low.    Management does not care about your home work life balance.  You will work 10-12 hours a day in this group without blinking. The department is full of 20somethings that live walking distance to the office, and drink away their troubles together late into the night.   If you have a family or do not live in the city, you should think twice about taking a role in this department.  You will not get home before 8pm most nights.  There are very few actual perks to this job. The office is sparsely appointed for employee comfort.   Promotional opportunities usually require a transfer to a different group.   100% Silo work.  Extremely high turnover, and you will be expected to pick up the slack.

headline: The people here are approachable and professional.
pros: Good work culture, people are friendly, and the salary for fresh grads is competitive. This is also a international company so I think there are chances for employees here to work on different branches outside their countries.
cons: I still can't say things because I haven't started working, just signed a contract. But they said that there will be team shifting so I guess there are times that I would be asked to work on undesirable schedules.

headline: Steady Bank with limited opportunity to grow
pros: Very stable. Good benefits: 401k matching, pension, HSA contribution, good dental and vision coverage. Executives are very open/approachable.
cons: Training is non existent but where it exists it is very basic. Majority of people working there just want to do the minimum to get by. There are a few who care, and they are worked to death since they are the only ones who can get the job done. Promotions depend more on department than quality of work.

headline: Diversity Managment
pros: Family oriented. Flexible hours. Employs lots of recent graduates.
cons: Slow movement on management track.

headline: Reconciliation
pros: It's a job.  Not much else.
cons: Low pay for such a critical position

headline: Painfully political
pros: Job stability - many people have worked all their adult lives at this company.
cons: No effort is ever good enough.  Salaries are lower than other companies, and raises are meted out in pennies.  Politics is ridiculously out of control, and the only criteria for advancement.     Diversity is a catch phrase, but the reality is a work environment that is highly discriminatory and condescending in Northern's treatment of lower level women, older people.  Token diversity is rampant, which is just as insulting as overt racism.  The atmosphere is cold, stiff, intolerant, and non-inclusive.  Lots of blame throwing.  Life long employees are celebrated dead weight who spend more time working the system than adding productive value or ideas.  People do not smile much in this region.

headline: Good Learning experience for Freshers

headline: Good company to start your career with.

headline: Conservative
pros: Friendly people to work  with, good  work-life balance,stable employer.
cons: Pays really less to start with, Narrow career scope

headline: Great Institution but headed in the wrong direction
pros: Northern Trust was built on their service and commitment to their clients.   For many years they were at the top of their game but are vulnerable now to some of the larger players particularly in the personal side of their business.   To their credit they are trying to innovate however they've lost significant talent over the past 5 years.
cons: Generally they do not have a leadership position in the market with their product and service offerings.   Very slow to adapt and initiatives take too long to complete.

headline: People-Centric Work Environment, but Ongoing Challenges to Transform
pros: The company prides itself in being people-centric (strong benefits package), both in its fiduciary relationship with clients as well as with its employees, or partners, internally.  Most managers are comfortable providing flexible work options, depending on team deliverables.  Several avenues for networking and career development, but only for those who can establish the right network.  Internal mobility is common and widely supported by managers who have themselves benefited from working across functional areas.
cons: Similar to the rest of the industry Northern Trust has been pushing large change initiatives to reduce expenses and raise revenues.  Lack of funding in budgets has limited opportunities for internal mobility and flatlined growth in most partners salary despite increased responsibilities and volume.  Change provides opportunities for individuals eager to enhance the company, but challenges the status quo that many partners benefit from due to skills or networks they've developed over 20+ years in the company.  Many decisions get made (or swayed) by personality or relationship of senior stakeholders despite effort put into group analysis and discussion.

headline: Very good culture, great reputation.
pros: Northern Trust offers a flexible work schedule, competitive benefits and a supportive work environment. It is a well respected, established name in the money management space and has a huge presence in Chicago.
cons: Northern Trust has a reputation of paying below the market average. Most employees are generalists and never become masters of one specific discipline.

headline: Good working environment, dinosaur bosses
pros:
Positive work life balance.  Yes, Bankers Hours still exist. (Most are 8-4 with a 90 minute lunch)
Some smart people.  It varies widely
Good benefits.  Sometimes to good for the company (see cons)
The bar is set pretty low.  Mediocrity is rewarded and encouraged because it gets work done and is non threatening to management.
Never rushed.
Recognition for any time put in working past normal hours.
cons:
Management insulates itself from the workers.
Old School.
MANY people are there to finish up their pension time and retire.  Veterans spend more time insulating themselves and consolidating their position than they do working.  Often spending cycles doing CYA rather than something productive.
Meetings drag as people seem more concerned about filling the time than getting something done
Mid level managers can take WEEKS to reply to an email just to display their power even if it is costing the company thousands of dollars a day.  Not an open door environment
Bottom Line: Management could be in a coma for three weeks before anyone would notice.

headline: "Old School" Firm
pros: Culture that built a great reputation serving clients well and supports work/life balance.  Senior management is extremely accessible and promotes internal networking.
cons: Slow moving; not receptive to change.  Overweighted with middle management that is out of touch with what is going on in the field.  Lack of accountability.

headline: Networking is crucial here
pros: A good place to start your career.  People are intelligent and know the business well.  If you are excellent at networking you will have more opportunities for career advancement.
cons: Advancement can be slow and it's more political (hence the networking above) and less of a meritocracy.  There are also a lot of inefficient HR or administrative processes that they are working to improve upon.

headline: Overall positive experience.
pros: The people are great -  friendly and supportive.  Salary is fair.  Work balance is very good.
cons: Business is very siloed and as a result not always very efficient.

headline: Stale Culture
pros: Best trust business on the planet.  Average investment management platform.  Pitiful private banking/lending culture.
cons: Stale culture.  Very few partners have any fire in the belly.  One could make a career of sliding by.  Bonuses are a joke even for top quartile performers.  Inquisitive partners are shunned as arrogant rather recognized as constructive challengers of convention.

headline: Good, But dirty politics
pros: Less work load.. one can enjoy social life
cons: no growth at all.. stay away from dirtypolitics

headline: Pretty good place
pros: People are nice.  Friendly environment
cons: Consensus often required for decisions which slow things down

headline: My experience there was wonderful and educational I enjoyed my employment there immensely.

cons: Not receiving all the information needed to setup new accounts and having those new clients stonewall you because they only want to correspond with the person who brought them into the company. The very small severance package that is given to employees that had not had the opportunity to gain more than 4 years there.

headline: Client Service rep
pros: The work environment Is very light, despite demanding clients. Management is not overwhelming with there demands.  Salary, considering scope of work, is in line with competitors.
cons: It's somewhat difficult get proper direction on procedures.  Directives are out of date and those that are updated are in a different area.  Management not hands on, you are often referred to other reps for help or difficult clients.

headline: Good place to start, don't stay too long.

headline: full of politics - canal office

- Compensation is non-existent. I've given out 1% raises.

headline: Custodians are cheap

headline: Good Experience but dirty politics
pros: It is a good place to work for freshers .Employee Oriented Company
cons: Lot of politics.I hated this place because of the dirty politics out there.

headline: Great Company
pros: Northern Trust is a very stable company and a good place to work. Every manager that I've had valued work/life balance, and was very considered and understanding. The Benefits are good.
cons: The pay is low and its really hard to move around within the company.

headline: Working with Northern Trust for more than 5 years- Good place to work
pros: Compensation is bad compared to other companies. Growth is too slow untill you have a good support from your senior management. But a peaceful company to work if you are not looking for quick promotion. Sports and other activities is the best thing i like in this company.
cons: Best place to work for youngsters.

headline: Overall good company to work for but management is hit or miss.
pros: This is a good place to start your career. You are encouraged to learn and grow within the company. It is also a great place to work if you really want stability and longevity with a company. Northern has an excellent reputation in the industry and the name carries weight. The opportunities to move around are tremendous and allows you to gain experience across many different areas. Depending on the area you work in, flex-time, work from home are options. The benefits, 401k, pension, vacation package is generous. There is a really friendly culture there is a sense of people working together as a team to get things done. The people make this a very enjoyable place to work.
cons:
While the benefits package are generous, the salaries are not competitive. There is a feeling that you are not there because of the money. The salary increases are also quite low and bonuses are discretionary so the feeling is that those who are management's favorites get the most.
Despite the fact that there are lay-offs, the rate is much lower than other banks in the financial industry. Overall there is a sense that once you are at the company you can build a career and have a stability. This can be positive and makes for very happy dedicated employee, however, unfortunately this also results in poor performing employees and managers remaining in their positions without consequences. This can be very frustrating when this is a manager because rather than address the problem employees will just move to another area because of the mobility within the company.

headline: Not performance oriented with respect to investment management
pros: Located in good city (Chicago).
cons: Not performance oriented; incentives for employees not aligned with investment management performance.

headline: Good company, great beneifts, but behind the times.
pros: Great Pay for entry positions, set schedule, good benefits, but pricey depending. Company loves to promote from within but will give a equal and fair chance for non-employee hiring. They alternate this well. Facility amenities nice, good vacation/ sick package, friendly environment mostly. Encourages new ideas, even rewards/ pays for them. Fun, interesting company events.
cons: Old Outdated systems, need for efficient, functional technological systems for clients and employees. Lots of passing the buck, with retail offices, when dealing with the call center. Many transferred calls with confused clients, who are upset they have to re-explain their issue to you. Some policies and practices are not client centered. Meaning they provide no resolution that would be efficient, nor practical for clients. Expect many confused and sometimes angry clients.

headline: Okish
pros: Northern Trust is a large, multinational company with offices accross the globe. It provides various financial services it its client which are apart from within the US mainly large financial institutions or corporations. There are a variety of different business units and sections.
cons: Given its size, Northern Trust has a very complicated structure which results in lack of visibilty, lack of ownership and makes it very difficult to navigate within.

headline: Analyst
pros: Great work environment. Always given an opportunity to learn something new.

cons: Management is very adament, no empowerment to the employees, Management is biased and supports the hirarchy with out investigation... loads of cost cutting... very conservative.. takes no risk hence profits never rises to the expectations.

headline: Very professional organization.

headline: I have been working at Northern Trust full-time for more than 5 years.

cons: Very conservative on compensation. Their moto is that they will pay you at the average of what the street is paying - so don't expect much.

headline: My experience at Northern Trust has been positive for me and my future career.
pros: -The opportunity to make a name for yourself within your team is there. You will work with management or Sr. management on a daily/weekly basis.
cons: Norther Trust has a very conservative nature which shows in the very dated systems that are used. I believe that NT is behind the curve on their technology which creates a very difficult work environment. Any technology advances involve using system patching through macros. NT does not have the reputation of very high compensation. Through my research I would say most other financial institutions have better compensation packages.

headline: Nice Experience

headline: Good Company
pros: Good work life balance, good culture. Depending on the business unit,, there is a lot of room for advancement; especially given that the average NT employee is not very motivated.
cons: Very conservative on compensation. Their moto is that they will pay you at the average of what the street is paying - so don't expect much..

headline: Stable, conservative and a great company to be associated with.
pros: As a company, it is very stable due to its conservative approach to business, has witnessed at least 3 major financial meltdown in the last century, yet sailed through successfully.  It is profitable year on year.  Good work ethics and advocate work-life balance.
cons: Not a great company for IT professionals.  It takes years to implement new technology, advanced platform or make any changes to the environment.  Decision making is highly centralized and doesn't involve any affiliate teams.  Hires very experienced IT Pros but doesn't give equitable role & responsibility.  Treat senior IT Pros as mere line managers to execute what is being told.  IT Pros will have least job satisfaction.

headline: AWESOME

headline: Nice people, but Unequal pay and workloads

High turnover. Work most weekends, 55+ hour work weeks. Poor bonus structure in operations. Very dated technology with little investment in this space. Most operational jobs are being relocated to India, poor job security in these roles. Incompetence and poor work ethic is acceptable.

headline: Great work environment.
pros:
1. Very good learning in banking domain.
2. good exposure.
3. very approachable management.
4. depending on teams flexible.
5. great for beginners 
6. excellent leave policies, they have mandatory 5 day continuous leave policy, annual leave for beginners is 22 sick leave 9 and emergency 3 plus you can carry forward leaves to next year.
7. In most of the cases the management is transparent in terms of promotions and rewards.
8. HR is approachable and takes complaints seriously although they may not do much about it you can be sure they will give you a solution. 
9. professional work environment.
cons:
1. some teams have extended work hours 10 - 14 hrs in peak season
2. women may not be happy with shift timings although the mgt is concerned and accommodates them.

headline: Good place to work for..

headline: Great History, Some Risks to the Future
pros: Great legacy of being the safe place for investors.  The firm is stable and many employees have been here for years.
cons: Company has fallen far behind competitors in technology.  To some extent the firm is riding on its laurels.  Also, the "care for customers first" culture seems to becoming eroded by a brokerage mentality of sell all the time and getting new business and revenues is the only thing that matters.  If this becomes more pervasive, the franchise is in serious danger, especially given the lack of investment in systems.  And, it's a bank.  Senior people get paid pretty well, everybody else, not so much.  Good place to have on your resume.  Career advancement will require changing employers.

headline: Stay as far away as you possibly can!
pros: It has a respectable name in the industry and looks decent on a rÃ©sumÃ©.
cons:
~Terrible management! They openly communicate that they don't care about any of your concerns and show arrogance along the way. 

~Micro management 

~Lack of trust in employees - they accuse employees of wrongdoing without any proof and treat them terribly. 

~No respect

~Too many office politics and affairs. It seems like everyone just sleeps around with each other.

~Unreasonably long work hours

~TERRIBLE PAY! It's almost an insult.

~They look for reasons to not pay out the pathetic bonuses.

~Raises are pathetic and also a slap in the face. Someone actually got a $400 raise so you do the math.

~Promotions are no more than a title change. Salary, bonuses, privileges and hours are not affected.  

~Indecent quality staff - majority of the people don't even seem like educated, classy people with solid experience.

~CRAZY TURNOVER!!! My department lost an average of 4 individuals per month. Hiring was constantly going on because people were constantly quitting. Majority of the talented employees found better opportunities and left the company as soon as they could.

~Outdated technology

~Very cheap company. They don't even provide free coffee.

headline: If you are considering a contract position, please be advised.
pros: Many of the team with whom you work are very competent and enthusiastic about the work which they do.
cons: Contractors are considered mere commodities. While all potential Contractors know that the reason they are hired is to fulfill an immediate need, there is a difference between coming into a busy department, and coming into a department where the work has been back-logged over several months. In addition to that backlog, add the assignments for which you were originally hired. Some (not all) management can sometimes be verbally abusive because you are, again, a mere commodity. You are put in a position, by that verbal abuse, as well as your own professional awareness and eagerness to do a good job, that you must put in unpaid time in order to get the job done. Overtime is rarely available, yet you feel obligated to stay beyond your scheduled shift, and are pressured to stay, by that abusive behavior, and the overwhelming amount of work which needs to be done.

headline: Solid but not great place to begin a career
pros: Since it's a big company there are lots of internal opportunities. Networking is great and encouraged; most people in higher positions are willing to speak with you. Great benefits and they treat employees very well.
cons: Super conservative, all respects (thinking, investing and salaries). They rarely fire anyone, people stay in the same position for 20 years.  Very low employee motivation. Raises and promotions can be very political.

headline: Not a challenging environment
pros: You have a LOT of flexibility.  Great for family man/woman.  Getting fired is near impossible.
cons: Pay is terrible.  Moving up within your department is difficult.  They don't get rid of under performing employees. The "training" they offer is a waste of time.  I couldn't believe I was paid to train for a month and when I was finally assigned to my team, I was told by everyone on the team to forget what I learned. Northern prides its self in being conservative, but I believe there is a difference between being conservative and being old fashioned. They need to get with the times.  I'll finish by saying again that their pay is terrible which is why they can't retain any talent.

headline: It's a conservative bank, what did you expect?
pros: #1 Vacation days, #2 an emphasis on charity and community service, #3 Overtime was very rare
cons: I have never worked anywhere with so many people just waiting it out for retirement, or with such a cultish deference to management in every aspect of their work life. The pay was not competitive, but then, not much is expected of you. Put all of that together and you get a stifling environment where there are 5 middle managers involved in every decision, with their main criteria being what the manager above them will accept. I constantly felt that my work was mediocre.

headline: Was once a good place to work

The good workers have to make up for the dead wieght and get burnt out.

headline: It was a great place to work in the 80's & 90's, but as management changed, so did the company, and not for the better.
pros: Good benefits and pay, and a good choice for customers or investors. The company still has some good managers, who actually manage, mentor, and support their staff, work in a compromising way with other departments, and who try to do the right thing for the company, their employees and the client.
cons: Women were considered an asset in the 80's & 90's, but the company has fallen back to the good old boy network.  Upper management brought in from the outside are concerned for their own jobs and not the jobs of the employees.  The company used to have a more family-oriented feel to it, but it's now more of a dog-eat-dog environment.  Outsourcing has replaced many employees, and one needs to continually watch their back for backstabbing management.  No oversight to ensure management treats employees respectfully or fairly.  Maybe the bank has just grown too large - sad.

headline: It's a great company to work for if you work in Bangalore, India
pros:
Generous vacation policy
Benefits used to be much better, but have been drastically cut in the past three years.
cons:
Notice that all the positive reviews of late have been from employees located in Bangalore, India. I'm sure this place has been good to them. However, in the U.S. it's a totally different experience and it is a negative one.

1. Benefits have been drastically cut in the past two years.
2. Low pay, minimal raises, and low bonuses (if any).
3. Antiquated technology. Poor internal systems.
4. Management asks you to "do more with less", but refuses to compensate you for all the extra work you take on.
5. No team environment. It's every man for himself. And if something should go wrong, the finger pointing begins.
6. Very difficult to get ahead in the organization, unless you are a management favorite. A smart, go-getter can easily get surpassed by a management favorite, who just does the minimum to get  by.
7. Senior management is so out of touch, they have no idea what it takes just to get the simplest task done.
8. There is a lot of reorganization. I have had six bosses in five years.
9/. Expenses have been cut to the bone; no technology upgrades, no coffee, no plastic utensils, no team outings. However, the company signs a multi-million, multi-year deal to sponsor the Northern Trust open. It seems senior management's love of golfing in Southern California in February is more important than doing what's right for the business and it's employees.

headline: Worst place I have ever worked
pros: There are no good things about working for Northern Trust.  Worked for many years and have never worked at a place where I could not find a single good quality about the place.
cons: The absolute worst working enviorment in my career.  Do not trust management, HR, or the Human Relations Department they do not protect the employees they will back managment only.  Stay clear of the Fund Administration Department.  The Head of the Fund Admin change about 2 years ago department went downhill from there.  Without a doubt the current head only manages his mangers and is clueless as to what goes on in his department.  He stays in his office with his door shut and has no interaction with anyone but managers.  The manager I reported to has absolutely no managment skills, and without a doubt a big zero when it comes to people skills.  She lacks interaction with her team much like her direct report plops in her chair and does not converse with her team at all.  Holds useless meetings not a very well liked individual.  They work you like a dog too many hours too little pay.  Pay is terrible raises what raises.  Bonus are really not existent if you want to call what they give a bonus. My advice stay as far away from Northern Trust as you can no job is better than working at Northern Trust.
